revision.text:
'''1995 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport. {{Year box}} ==[[Alpine skiing]]== * [[Alpine Skiing World Cup]] ** Men's overall season champion: [[Alberto Tomba]], [[Italy]] ** Women's overall season champion: [[Vreni Schneider]], [[Switzerland]] ==[[American football]]== * [[Super Bowl XXIX]] – [[San Francisco 49ers]] won 49-26 over the [[San Diego Chargers]] * The [[World League of American Football]] is resumed after 2 years without play. [[Frankfurt Galaxy]] win the [[World Bowl]] 26-22 over the [[Amsterdam Admirals]]. * [[Orange Bowl]] (1994 season) ** The [[Nebraska Cornhuskers]] won 24-17 over the [[Miami Hurricanes]] to win the national championship ==[[Association football]]== * [[FIFA Women's World Cup]] – [[Norway]] won 2-0 over [[Germany]] * [[Intercontinental Cup (football)|World Club Championship]] – [[AFC Ajax]] defeat [[Grêmio Foot-Ball Porto Alegrense|Grêmio]] 0-0 (4-3 in penalty shootout) * [[UEFA Champions League]] – [[AFC Ajax]] defeat [[A.C. Milan]] 1-0 * [[Campeonato Brasileiro Série A]] – [[Botafogo de Futebol e Regatas|Botafogo FR]] defeat [[Santos FC]] 3-2 (aggregate score) * [[Copa Libertadores da América]] – [[Grêmio Foot-Ball Porto Alegrense|Grêmio]] defeat [[Atlético Nacional]] 4-2 (aggregate score) *[[Blackburn Rovers]] won the [[Premier League]], denying [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] a hat-trick of titles * December 15 – European football is shaken to its foundations when the [[European Court of Justice]] [[Bosman ruling|rules]] that: ** Clubs in the European Union cannot be restricted from signing foreign players who are nationals of EU member states ** Players under contract to clubs in the EU are entitled to a [[Free transfer (football)|free transfer]] at the end of their contracts ==[[Australian rules football]]== * [[1995 AFL season|Australian Football League]] ** The [[Fremantle Football Club|Fremantle Dockers]] join the league ** [[Carlton Football Club|Carlton]] wins the 99th AFL premiership beating [[Geelong Football Club|Geelong]] 21.15 (141) to 11.14 (80) ** [[Carlton Football Club|The Blues]] become the first team to win 23 games in an AFL season or twenty in a home-and-away season ** [[Brownlow Medal]] awarded to [[Paul Kelly (footballer)|Paul Kelly]] ([[Sydney Swans]]) * [[South Australian National Football League]] ** [[Sturt Football Club|Sturt]] suffer the ignominy of going [[imperfect season|winless]] for [[1995 Sturt Football Club season|a full 22-match season]], the only occurrence thereof in a major Australian Rules league. ==[[Baseball]]== * [[1995 World Series|World Series]] – [[1995 Atlanta Braves season|Atlanta Braves]] won 4 games to 2 over [[1995 Cleveland Indians season|the Cleveland Indians]]. The Series MVP was [[Tom Glavine]], Atlanta * September 6 - [[Cal Ripken Jr.]] breaks [[Lou Gehrig]]'s record of playing 2130 consecutive games. * [[1995 California Angels season|California Angels]] lose a 13-game lead over [[1995 Seattle Mariners season|the Seattle Mariners]], and lose the division title in a one-game playoff. ==[[Basketball]]== * [[NCAA Men's Basketball Championship]] – ** UCLA wins 89-78 over Arkansas, giving the Bruins their first National College Basketball Championship in 20 years, and 11th overall. * [[National Basketball Association|NBA Finals]] ** [[Houston Rockets]] win 4 games to 0 over the [[Orlando Magic]] * [[National Basketball League (Australia)]] Finals: ** [[Perth Wildcats]] defeated the [[North Melbourne Giants]] 2-1 in the best-of-three final series. * A first season of [[Chinese Basketball Association|China Professional Basketball Men's League]] game held on December 10.{{page needed|date=July 2017}} ==[[Boxing]]== * March 11 to March 27 – '''[[Boxing at the 1995 Pan American Games|Pan American Games]]''' held in [[Mar del Plata, Argentina]].* May 6 – [[Oscar de la Hoya]] scored a second-round TKO in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] over [[Rafael Ruelas]] to retain his World Lightweight Championship. ==[[Canadian football]]== * For the first time in history, the Grey Cup went to an [[United States|American]]-based team. * [[Grey Cup]] – ** [[Baltimore Stallions]] win 37-20 over the [[Calgary Stampeders]] * [[Vanier Cup]] – ** [[Calgary Dinos]] win 54-24 over the [[Western Ontario Mustangs]] ==[[Cricket]]== * December 26 in [[Melbourne]] – [[Umpire (cricket)|umpire]] [[Darrell Hair]] no balls [[Sri Lanka]]n spinner [[Muttiah Muralitharan]] seven times for throwing in the second [[Test cricket|Test]] against [[Australia]]. ==[[Cycling]]== * [[Giro d'Italia]] won by [[Tony Rominger]] of [[Switzerland]] * [[Tour de France]] - [[Miguel Indurain]] of [[Spain]] * [[UCI Road World Championships – Men's road race]] – [[Abraham Olano]] of [[Spain]] ==[[Dogsled racing]]== * [[Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race|Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race Champion]] – ** [[Doug Swingley]] won with lead dogs: ''Vic'' & ''Elmer'' ==[[Field hockey]]== * Men's Champions Trophy: Germany * Women's Champions Trophy: Australia * Men's European Nations Cup: Germany * Women's European Nations Cup: Netherlands ==[[Figure skating]]== * [[World Figure Skating Championships]] – ** Men's champion: [[Elvis Stojko]], [[Canada]] ** Ladies' champion: [[Chen Lu (figure skater)|Chen Lu]], [[China]] ** Pairs' champions: [[Radka Kovariková]] / [[René Novotný]], [[Czech Republic]] ** Ice dancing champions: [[Oksana Grishuk]] / [[Evgeny Platov]], [[Russia]] ==[[Gaelic Athletic Association]]== *'''[[Camogie]]''' ** All-Ireland Camogie Champion: [[Cork GAA|Cork]] ** National Camogie League: [[Cork GAA|Cork]] *'''[[Gaelic football]]''' ** [[All-Ireland Senior Football Championship]] – [[Dublin GAA|Dublin]] 1-10 died [[Tyrone GAA|Tyrone]] 0-12 ** [[National Football League (Ireland)|National Football League]] – [[Derry GAA|Derry]] 0-12 died [[Donegal GAA|Donegal]] 0-8 *'''[[Ladies' Gaelic football]]''' ** All-Ireland Senior Football Champion: [[Waterford GAA|Waterford]] ** National Football League: [[Waterford GAA|Waterford]] *'''[[Hurling]]''' ** [[All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship]] – [[Clare GAA|Clare]] 1-13 died [[Offaly GAA|Offaly]] 2-8 ** [[National Hurling League]] – ==[[Golf]]== '''Men's professional''' * [[Masters Tournament]] - [[Ben Crenshaw]] * [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] - [[Corey Pavin]] * [[The Open Championship|British Open]] - [[John Daly (golfer)|John Daly]] * [[PGA Championship]] - [[Steve Elkington]] * [[PGA Tour]] money leader - [[Greg Norman]] - $1,654,959 * [[Champions Tour|Senior PGA Tour]] money leader - [[Jim Colbert]] - $1,444,386 * [[Ryder Cup]] - [[Europe]] won 14½ to 13½ over the [[United States]] in team golf. '''Men's amateur''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] - [[Gordon Sherry]] * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|U.S. Amateur]] - [[Tiger Woods]] * [[European Amateur]] - [[Sergio García]] '''Women's professional''' * [[Kraft Nabisco Championship|Nabisco Dinah Shore]] - [[Nanci Bowen]] * [[LPGA Championship]] - [[Kelly Robbins]] * [[United States Women's Open Championship (golf)|U.S. Women's Open]] - [[Annika Sörenstam]] * [[du Maurier Classic|Classique du Maurier]] - [[Jenny Lidback]] * [[LPGA|LPGA Tour]] money leader - [[Annika Sörenstam]] - $666,533 ==[[Harness racing]]== * [[North America Cup]] - [[David's Pass]] * [[Triple Crown of Harness Racing for Pacers|United States Pacing Triple Crown races]] – *# [[Cane Pace]] - [[Mattgrilla Gorilla]] *# [[Little Brown Jug (horse racing)|Little Brown Jug]] - [[Nick's Fantasy]] *# [[Messenger Stakes]] - [[David's Pass]] * [[Triple Crown of Harness Racing for Trotters|United States Trotting Triple Crown races]] – *# [[Hambletonian Stakes|Hambletonian]] - [[Tagliabue]] *# [[Yonkers Trot]] - *# [[Kentucky Futurity]] - [[CR Trackmaster]] * [[Australian Inter Dominion Harness Racing Championship]] – ** Pacers: [[Golden Reign]] ** Trotters: [[Call Me Now]] ==[[Horse racing]]== '''Steeplechases''' * [[Cheltenham Gold Cup]] – [[Master Oats]] * [[Grand National]] – [[Royal Athlete]] '''Flat races''' * Australia – [[Melbourne Cup]] won by [[Doriemus]] * Canada – [[Queen's Plate]] won by [[Regal Discovery]] * France – [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] won by [[Lammtarra]] * Ireland – [[Irish Derby Stakes]] won by [[Winged Love]] * Japan – [[Japan Cup]] won by [[Lando (horse)|Lando]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|English Triple Crown races]]: *# [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Pennekamp]] *# [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Lammtarra]] *# [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Classic Cliche]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|United States Triple Crown races]]: *# [[Kentucky Derby]] – [[Thunder Gulch]] *# [[Preakness Stakes]] – [[Timber Country]] *# [[Belmont Stakes]] – [[Thunder Gulch]] * [[Breeders' Cup]] World Thoroughbred Championships: *# [[Breeders' Cup Classic]] – [[Cigar (horse)|Cigar]] *# [[Breeders' Cup Distaff]] – [[Inside Information (horse)|Inside Information]] *# [[Breeders' Cup Juvenile]] – [[Unbridled's Song]] *# [[Breeders' Cup Juvenile Fillies]] – [[My Flag]] *# [[Breeders' Cup Mile]] – [[Ridgewood Pearl]] *# [[Breeders' Cup Sprint]] – [[Desert Stormer]] *# [[Breeders' Cup Turf]] – [[Northern Spur]] ==[[Ice hockey]]== * [[Art Ross Trophy]] as the [[National Hockey League|NHL]]'s leading scorer during the regular season: [[Jaromír Jágr|Jaromir Jagr]], [[Pittsburgh Penguins]] * [[Hart Memorial Trophy]] – for the [[National Hockey League|NHL]]'s Most Valuable Player: [[Eric Lindros]], [[Philadelphia Flyers]] * [[Stanley Cup]] – [[New Jersey Devils]] win 4 games to 0 over the [[Detroit Red Wings]] * [[World Hockey Championship]] ** Men's champion: [[Finland]] defeated [[Sweden]] ** Junior Men's champion: [[Canada]] defeated [[Russia]] ==[[Lacrosse]]== * [[National Lacrosse League|Major Indoor Lacrosse League]] Championship: The [[Philadelphia Wings (1987–2014)|Philadelphia Wings]] win 15–14 over the [[Rochester Knighthawks]] after overtime. * [[Mann Cup]] for the [[Canada|Canadian]] [[box lacrosse]] championship: [[Six Nations Chiefs]] of [[Major Series Lacrosse]] * Inaugural [[European Lacrosse Championships]] – [[England]] defeats [[Czech Republic]] ==[[Mixed martial arts]]== The following is a list of major noteworthy MMA events during 1995 in chronological order. Before 1997, the [[Ultimate Fighting Championship]] (UFC) was considered the only major MMA organization in the world and featured much fewer rules then are used in modern MMA. {{s-start}} |- |align=center style="border-style: none none solid solid; background: #e3e3e3"|Date |align=center style="border-style: none none solid solid; background: #e3e3e3"|Event |align=center style="border-style: none none solid solid; background: #e3e3e3"|Alternate Name/s |align=center style="border-style: none none solid solid; background: #e3e3e3"|Location |align=center style="border-style: none none solid solid; background: #e3e3e3"|Attendance |align=center style="border-style: none none solid solid; background: #e3e3e3"|PPV Buyrate |align=center style="border-style: none none solid solid; background: #e3e3e3"|Notes |-align=center |April 7 |[[UFC 5|UFC 5: The Return of the Beast]] |{{N/A}} |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Charlotte, North Carolina|Charlotte]], [[North Carolina]], [[United States|US]] |6,000 |260,000 |{{small|UFC rule change, introduction to a single 30 minute round. Introduction of superfights. [[Rorion Gracie]] and [[Royce Gracie]] cut there involvement with the UFC following this event.}} |-align=center |July 14 |[[UFC 6|UFC 6: Clash of the Titans]] |{{N/A}} |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Casper, Wyoming|Casper]], [[Wyoming]], [[United States|US]] |2,700 |240,000 |{{small|UFC rule change, referee is given the authority to restart the fight. Introduction to additional 5 minute extension to 30 minute round. Introduction of superfight titles.}} |-align=center |September 8 |[[UFC 7|UFC 7: The Brawl in Buffalo]] |{{N/A}} |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States|US]] |9,000 |190,000 |{{N/A}} |-align=center |December 16 |[[Ultimate Ultimate 1995|The Ultimate Ultimate]] |Ultimate Ultimate 1995
UFC 7.5 |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Denver]], [[Colorado]], [[United States|US]] |2,800 |{{N/A}} |{{small|Time limits were redefined for this event. 15 minutes in quarterfinal fights, 18 minutes for semi-final fights, and 27 minutes with a possible 3 minute overtime for the final fight.}} |-align=center {{s-end}} ==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1995 in motorsport|List of 1995 motorsport champions}} ==[[Radiosport]]== * First [[International Amateur Radio Union|IARU]] Region III [[Amateur Radio Direction Finding]] Championships held in [[Japan]]. * First [[High Speed Telegraphy]] World Championship held in [[Siófok]], [[Hungary]]. ==[[Rugby league]]== *Australian international representative forward [[Ian Roberts (rugby league)|Ian Roberts]] became the first high-profile Australian sports person and first rugby footballer in the world to come out to the public as gay.{{cite web|last=Peter|first=O'Shea|title=Out of the field|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2WQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA54#v=onepage&q&f=false|work=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]|publisher=Here Publishing|accessdate=10 October 2011}} * March 5 – [[Carcassonne, France|Carcassonne]], France: last match of the [[1995 European Rugby League Championship|1995 European Championship]] is played with Wales finishing on top of the table. * March 10 – [[Auckland]], New Zealand: newly formed [[Auckland Warriors]] club play their first match: a 25-22 loss to the [[Brisbane Broncos]] at [[Mt Smart Stadium|Ericsson Stadium]] before 29,220. * April 29 – [[London, England|London]], England: [[1994–95 Rugby Football League season#Challenge Cup|1994-95 Challenge Cup]] tournament culminates in [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]]'s 30-10 win over [[Leeds Rhinos|Leeds]] in the final at [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]] before 78,550. * May 31 – [[Melbourne, Australia|Melbourne]], Australia: [[1995 State of Origin]] is wrapped up by [[Queensland State of Origin Team|Queensland]] in game two of the three-match series against [[New South Wales rugby league team|New South Wales]] at the [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] before 52,994. * September 24 – [[Sydney, Australia|Sydney]], Australia: [[1995 ARL season]] culminates in the [[Sydney Bulldogs]]' 17-4 win over the [[Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles]] in the grand final at the [[Sydney Football Stadium]] before 41,127. * October 24 – [[Bury, Greater Manchester|Bury]], England: [[1995 Rugby League Emerging Nations Tournament|1995 Emerging Nations Tournament]] culminates in the Cook Islands' 22-6 win over Ireland in the final at [[Gigg Lane]] before 4,147. * October 28 – [[London, England|London]], England: [[1995 Rugby League World Cup|1995 World Cup]] culminates in Australia's 16-8 win over England in the final at Wembley Stadium before 66,540. ==[[Rugby union]]== * 101st [[Six Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is won by [[England national rugby union team|England]] who complete the [[Grand Slam (rugby union)|Grand Slam]] * [[1995 Rugby World Cup|Rugby World Cup]] is won by hosts [[South Africa national rugby union team|South Africa]] 15–12 over [[New Zealand national rugby union team|New Zealand]] in the final with an extra-time drop goal by [[Joel Stransky]] * 26 August – [[International Rugby Board|International Rugby Football Board]] lifts the century-old ban on [[professionalism]] ==[[Snooker]]== * [[1995 World Snooker Championship|World Snooker Championship]] – [[Stephen Hendry]] beats [[Nigel Bond]] 18-9 * [[Snooker world rankings|World rankings]] – [[Stephen Hendry]] remains [[List of world number-one snooker players|world number one]] for [[Snooker season 1995/1996|1995/96]] ==[[Swimming (sport)|Swimming]]== * February 11 – [[Danyon Loader]] swims world record in the Men's 400m Freestyle, while [[Mark Foster (swimmer)|Mark Foster]] betters the world record in the Men's 50m Butterfly and [[Sandra Völker]] swims a European record in the Women's 50m Backstroke. * February 18 – [[Australia]]'s [[Angela Kennedy]] breaks the world record in the Women's 100m Butterfly (short course): 58:77 * [[Swimming at the 1995 Pan American Games|XII Pan American Games]], held in [[Mar del Plata, Argentina]] (March 12 – 18) * [[European LC Championships 1995|22nd European LC Championships]], held in [[Vienna, Austria]] (August 22 – 27) ** Germany wins the most medals (28), Russia the most gold medals (14) * [[1995 FINA Short Course World Championships|II. World Short Course Championships]], held in [[Rio de Janeiro, Brazil|Rio de Janeiro]], Brazil (November 30 – December 3) ** December 2 – [[PR China]]'s [[Liu Limin]] breaks the world record in the Women's 100m Butterfly (short course): 58:68 ** December 3 – Australia wins the most medals (26), and the most gold medals (12) ==[[Taekwondo]]== * [[1995 World Taekwondo Championships|World Championships]] held in [[Manila]], [[Philippines]] ==[[Tennis]]== * [[Grand Slam in tennis]] men's results: *# [[Australian Open]] – [[Andre Agassi]] *# [[French Open]] – [[Thomas Muster]] *# [[Wimbledon championships]] – [[Pete Sampras]] *# [[US Open (tennis)|US Open]] – [[Pete Sampras]] * [[Grand Slam in tennis]] women's results: *# [[Australian Open]] – [[Mary Pierce]] *# [[French Open]] – [[Steffi Graf]] *# [[Wimbledon championships]] – [[Steffi Graf]] *# [[US Open (tennis)|US Open]] – [[Steffi Graf]] * [[Davis Cup]] – The [[United States Davis Cup team|USA]] wins 3–2 over [[Russia Davis Cup team|Russia]]. * [[Fed Cup]] – [[Spain Fed Cup team|Spain]] wins 3–2 over the [[United States Fed Cup team|USA]] in the first Fed Cup to bear that name, and the first to employ a Davis Cup-style format. ==[[Volleyball]]== * Men's World Cup: Italy * Men's European Championship: Italy * Women's World Cup: Cuba * Women's European Championship: Netherlands ==[[Water polo]]== * Men's World Cup: Hungary * Men's European Championship]: Italy * Women's European Championship: Italy ==[[Yacht racing]]== * New Zealand wins its first [[America's Cup]] as ''[[NZL 32|Black Magic]]'', of the [[Royal New Zealand Yacht Squadron]], beats defender ''Young America'', from the [[San Diego Yacht Club]], 5 races to 0 ==[[Multi-sport event]]s== * Twelfth [[1995 Pan American Games|Pan American Games]] held in [[Mar del Plata, Argentina]] * Sixth [[1995 All-Africa Games|All-Africa Games]] held in [[Harare, Zimbabwe]] * 18th [[1995 Summer Universiade|Summer Universiade]] held in [[Fukuoka, Fukuoka|Fukuoka]], [[Japan]] * 17th [[1995 Winter Universiade|Winter Universiade]] held in [[Jaca]], [[Spain]] * 18th [[1995 Southeast Asian Games|SEA Games]] held in [[Chiang Mai]], [[Thailand]] ==Awards== * [[Associated Press Athlete of the Year#List of award winners|Associated Press Male Athlete of the Year]] – [[Cal Ripken Jr.]], [[Major League Baseball]] * [[Associated Press Athlete of the Year#List of award winners|Associated Press Female Athlete of the Year]] – [[Rebecca Lobo]], [[College basketball]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Sports by year 1951 – 2000}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1995 In Sports}} [[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1995 in sports| ]]

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Ozeki]] (link changed to [[Ōzeki]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
{{Unsourced|date=May 2013}} The following are the events in professional [[sumo]] during [[1996]].
==Tournaments== *Hatsu [[honbasho|basho]], [[Ryogoku Kokugikan]], [[Tokyo]], 7 January – 21 January *Haru basho, [[Osaka Prefectural Gymnasium]], [[Osaka]], 10 March – 24 March *Natsu basho, Ryogoku Kokugikan, Tokyo, 12 May – 26 May *Nagoya basho, [[Aichi Prefectural Gymnasium]], [[Nagoya]], 7 July – 21 July *Aki basho, Ryogoku Kokugikan, Tokyo, 8 September – 22 September *Kyushu basho, [[Fukuoka Kokusai Center|Fukuoka International Centre]], [[Kyushu]], 9 November – 23 November
==News==
===January=== *[[Ōzeki|Ozeki]] [[Takanonami]] wins his first top division [[yusho]], defeating his [[yokozuna (sumo)|yokozuna]] stablemate [[Takanohana]] in a playoff after both record 14–1 scores. [[Takatoriki]] is third on 11–4 and wins the Fighting Spirit Prize, shared with [[Kenko Satoshi|Kenko]] and newcomer [[Tamakasuga]]. [[Sekiwake]] [[Kaio Hiroyuki|Kaio]] gets the Outstanding Performance Award. [[Takeshi Rikio|Rikio]] wins the juryo championship after a playoff with [[Wakahayato]]. [[Saganobori]], a former [[maegashira]] who has been fighting in the unsalaried ranks for three years, retires.
===March=== *Takanohana wins his 12th championship, finishing on 14–1, two wins ahead of his stablemate and brother [[Wakanohana Masaru|Wakanohana]] and sekiwake [[Musoyama]], who gets the Technique Award. [[Asahiyutaka]] is the only man to beat Takanohana and wins the Outstanding Performance Award. [[Kotonowaka]] wins eleven and the Fighting Spirit Award. [[Kyokushuzan]] wins the juryo yusho after a playoff with [[Saigo Kazuyoshi|Saigo]]. Former ozeki [[Kirishima Kazuhiro|Kirishima]] retires, as do former maegashira [[Owakamatsu]] and [[Tamakairiki]] (who has fallen to the [[jonidan]] division).
===May=== [[File:Konishiki.jpg|150px|thumb|right|Konishiki at the Kokugikan in May 1996.]] *Takanohana wins with a 14–1 record again, two wins ahead of Wakanohana and Takanonami, underlining the dominance of [[Futagoyama stable]]. Yokozuna [[Akebono Taro|Akebono]] returns from three tournaments sidelined by injury to score 10–5. Tamakasuga wins the Technique Prize and Kaio the Outstanding Performance Award. Veteran former ozeki [[Konishiki]] avoids demotion and certain retirement by winning ten bouts from maegashira 14. Rikio wins his second juryo championship. The [[makushita]] yusho is won by [[Dejima Takeharu|Dejima]].
===July=== *At the Nagoya basho, Takanonami is eliminated from the yusho race on the final day when he is defeated by Kaio. The championship is decided in the final bout between Takanohana and Akebono, tied on 12–2. Takanohana wins to claim his 14th championship, while Akebono has his first runner-up performance since September 1995. Takatoriki wins his eighth Fighting Spirit Prize. Kaio and Kotonowaka share the Outstanding Performance Prize. The 95 kg [[Mainoumi]] is injured when the 275 kg [[Konishiki]] falls on his leg. He has to withdraw from the tournament, meaning he will fall to juryo. [[Daizen Takahiro|Daizen]] wins his second juryo championship. Former maegashira [[Kiraiho]] retires. Kyokushuzan becomes the first wrestler from [[Mongolia]] to earn promotion to the top division.
===September=== *Takanohana wins four consecutive championships for the first time. He finishes with an unbeaten 15–0 score (zensho-yusho), his fourth. Wakanohana, Takatoriki and [[Musashimaru]] all finish four wins behind on 11–4. Takatoriki shares the Fighting Spirit Prize with Asahiyutaka. [[Kotonishiki]] wins ten bouts from the komusubi rank and receives his sixth Technique Prize. [[Tochiazuma Daisuke|Tochiazuma]] wins the juryo championship, his fifth yusho in five different divisions. Former maegashira [[Kasugafuji]], [[Hitachiryu]] and [[Kyokugozan]] all retire.
===November=== *Takanohana misses the first tournament of his career after injuring his back on tour. In his absence Musashimaru wins his second championship in a five-way playoff after he, Wakanohana, Akebono, Takanonami, and Kaio all finish on 11–4. Kaio receives the Fighting Spirit Prize alongside newcomer Tochiazuma. [[Tosanoumi]] wins the Outstanding Performance Award. [[Tochinonada]] wins the juryo title in his debut. Former komusubi [[Kyokudozan]] retires to become a politician in the [[Diet of Japan]].
==Deaths== *4 Jan: Former maegashira [[Oedo Yuji|Oedo]], former Irumagawa Oyakata, aged 73. *14 Jan: Former komusubi [[Ohikari Sadayuki|Ohikari]], former Onomatsu Oyakata, aged 68. *14 April: Former sekiwake [[Kotetsuyama Toyoya|Kotetsuyama]], former Onaruto Oyakata, aged 53. *8 Dec: Kagamiyama Oyakata, the former yokozuna [[Kashiwado]], aged 58.
==See also== *[[Glossary of sumo terms]] *[[List of past sumo wrestlers]] *[[List of years in sumo]] *[[List of yokozuna]]
{{Years in sumo}}
[[Category:Years in sumo]] [[Category:1996 in sports|Sumo]]

revision.comment: /* Post Season */ merge from [[2010 BFL playoffs]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox BFL season | year = 2010 | image = | image_caption = | number_of_teams = 15 | regular_season = February 14 | playoff_start = May 9 | playoff_end = May 16 | championship_bowl = [[Belgian Bowl XXIII]] | bowl_date = May 29 | championship_location = [[Brussels]] | champions_BB = [[West Flanders Tribes]] | champions_FFL = [[West Flanders Tribes]] | champions_LFFAB = [[Brussels Tigers]] }} The '''2010 season''' of the [[Belgian Football League]] (BFL) is the regular season played in the Belgium. The first week starts on 14 February 2010 and ends with the 12th week May 2. Then the Playoffs follow in the 13th and 14th week. The 2 remaining teams then compete in the championship [[Belgian Bowl XXIII]]. This is played in the 16th week on 29 May 2010 ==Regular season== ===Regular Season overview=== The FFL schedules two games at one location for saving on transportationcosts for referees and the costs of renting an ambulance and first aid responders. Half of the time, teams are playing virtually at home but actually play at the hosting team's homefield due to these costsaving measures. {| bgcolor="#f7f8ff" cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" border="1" style="font-size: 90%; border: gray solid 1px; border-collapse: collapse;" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! style=background-color:yellow colspan=7 |''' [[Flemish American Football League|FFL]] {{cite web|url=http://americanfootball.be/index.php?page=seizoen2010 |title=Flemish American Football League |publisher=AmericanFootball.be |date= |accessdate=2011-05-15}} |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" !Week!! The '''2014 FILA Wrestling World Cup - Women's freestyle''' was the second of a set of three FILA Wrestling World Cups in 2014 - one for each major discipline. The event took place in Tokyo, Japan on March 15 and 16, 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.themat.com/section.php?section_id=4&page=results|title=USA Wrestling - Features, Events, Results - Team USA|publisher=}} ==Final standings== 1. {{JPN}}
2. {{RUS}}
3. {{CHN}}
4. {{CAN}}
5. {{MGL}}
6. {{USA}}
7. {{HUN}}
8. {{UKR}} == See also == *[[2014 FILA Wrestling World Cup - Men's freestyle]] *[[2014 FILA Wrestling World Cup - Men's Greco-Roman]] == References == {{reflist}} {{Wrestling World Cup}} {{Summersport season 2014–15}} [[Category:2014 Wrestling World Cup]] [[Category:2014 in Japanese sport]] [[Category:International wrestling competitions hosted by Japan]] [[Category:2014 in women's sport wrestling|World]] {{Wrestling-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Alba Regia Sportcsarnok | nickname = | image = | fullname = | location = [[Székesfehérvár]], [[Hungary]] | coordinates = {{coord|47|11|29.3|N|18|25|09.9|E|type:landmark}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1978 | renovated = 1999 | expanded = 2014 | closed = | demolished = | owner = Municipality of Székesfehérvár | operator = Municipality of Székesfehérvár | surface = Parquet | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = '''ARÉV Sportcentrum'''

'''Alba Regia Sportcsarnok'''

'''David Kornel Basketball Academy'''
2004-present | capacity = 3,000 (basketball){{cite web|url=http://www.championsleague.basketball/17-18/2609/Alba-Fehervar-Kalev-Cramo/#iset=42b05ff0-fefa-4909-b605-4746e4031e43&iid=083d5bd7-7d33-4c36-9e1d-20fd027b13de|title=Alba Fehérvár vs BC Kalev Cramo|publisher=FIBA Basketball Champions League|accessdate=26 September 2017}}
5,000 (concerts){{cite web|url=https://www.jegymester.hu/hun/PlaceInfo/81029/Alba-Regia-Sportcsarnok|title=Jegymester|publisher=Jegymester.hu|accessdate=11 June 2011|language=Hungarian}} | dimensions = 54 x 36 m{{cite web|url=http://www.albakosar.hu/sportcsarnok|title=Sportcsarnok|publisher=Alba Fehérvár Official Website|accessdate=11 June 2011|language=Hungarian}} | scoreboard = }} '''Alba Regia Sportcsarnok''' is an indoor arena in [[Székesfehérvár]], [[Hungary]]. It hosts a number of sport clubs from amateur to professional level, with 2017 Hungarian basketball championship winner [[Alba Fehérvár]] being its most notable tenant. ==Features== The 650 square-meter field can be used for any indoor sports (basketball, mini-football, table-tennis, box events etc.) except handball. The sport center has a 500 square-meter gym with qualified trainers who can help to the sport lovers. In the hall there's a café and bar. Alba Regia Sportcentrum has 3,000 seating places for basketball events, that can be expanded by further 1000 seats at the field if necessary. For other events, such as concerts and shows, the figures can go up to 5,000, including standing places. ==Events== * 2015 [[FIBA Europe Under-20 Championship]] (Division B) * 2016-2017 [[FIBA Europe Cup]] games * 2017 [[FIBA Champions League]] games * 2017-2018 [[FIBA Europe Cup]] games * 2017 [[Fight Arena International Professional Fighting Gala]] * 2017 [[Whitney - Queen of The Night ]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Székesfehérvár]] [[Category:Sport in Székesfehérvár]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Hungary]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Hungary]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1978]] [[Category:1978 establishments in Hungary]]

/* Bare Knuckle Fighting Championship */
revision.text:
{{Infobox martial art |image = John L Sullivan.jpg |imagecaption = Irish American bare-knuckle boxer [[John L. Sullivan]] |imagesize = |name = |aka = Fisticuffs, Prizefighting, Classical Pugilism |focus = [[Strike (attack)|Striking]] |country = England<ref>Ollhoff, Jim (2008). '' Martial Arts Around the Globe (The World of Martial Arts)''. Abdo Group. pp. 20-21. ISBN 1599289793</ref> |creator = Unknown |parenthood = [[Ancient Greek boxing]], [[Street fighting]] }}
'''Bare-knuckle boxing''' (also known as '''bare-knuckle''', '''prizefighting''', '''fist fight''' or '''fisticuffs''') is the original form of [[boxing]], closely related to ancient [[combat sport]]s. It involves two individuals fighting without [[boxing gloves]] or other padding on their hands.
The difference between [[street fighting]] and a bare-knuckle boxing match is that the latter has an accepted set of rules, such as not striking a downed opponent.
==Early history== The first bare-knuckle champion of England was [[James Figg]], who claimed the title in 1719 and held it until his retirement in 1730. Before Jack Broughton, the first idea of current boxing originated from James Figg, who is viewed as the organizer of cutting edge boxing. In 1719, he set up a 'pugilistic foundation' and charged himself as 'a professional in the Noble Science of Defense' to instruct boxers on the utilization of clench hands, sword, and quarterstaff. Noted champions were [[Jack Broughton]], [[Elizabeth Wilkinson]], [[Daniel Mendoza]], [[Jem Belcher]], [[Hen Pearce]], [[John Gully]], [[Tom Cribb]], [[Tom Spring]], [[Jem Ward]], [[James Burke (boxer)|James Burke]], [[William Thompson (boxer)|William "Bendigo" Thompson]], [[Ben Caunt]], [[William Perry (boxer)|William Perry]], [[Tom Sayers]] and [[Jem Mace]].<ref name="BKC">{{citation |url=http://www.georgianindex.net/Sport/Boxing/champ-boxers.html |title=The Bare Knuckle Champions of England |accessdate=17 April 2009}}</ref>
The record for the longest bare-knuckle fight is listed as 6 hours and 15 minutes for a match between James Kelly and Jonathan Smith, fought near Fiery Creek, Victoria, Australia, on December 3, 1855, when Smith gave in after 17 rounds.<ref name="Bells Life in Sidney and Sporting Reviewer">{{citation |title=The Victoria Ring |newspaper=[[Bell's Life in Sydney and Sporting Reviewer]] |date=22 December 1855 |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-page5326638}}</ref>
The bare-knuckle fighter [[Jem Mace]] is listed as having the longest professional career of any fighter in history.<ref name="Bare Knuckle Records">{{cite web|url=http://www.trivia-library.com/a/strange-trivia-in-sports-boxing.htm|title=Synonyms Thesaurus With Definitions and Antonyms|work=trivia-library.com}}</ref> He fought for more than 35 years into his 60s,<ref>James B. Roberts, Alexander G. Skutt, [https://www.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=aA2LO_DGdu4C&oi=fnd&pg=PA6&dq=jem+mace+boxer&ots=4vq4IwfUIo&sig=oGsBbyh-GYQ5tBgfXKKx0BFr54o#v=onepage&q=mace&f=false ''The Boxing Register: International Boxing Hall of Fame Official Record Book'']</ref> and recorded his last exhibition bout in 1909 at the age of 79.
Professional bare-knuckle boxing was never legal under any federal or state laws in the United States until Wyoming became the first to legalize on March 20, 2018. Prior to that date, the chief sanctioning organization for bare-knuckle boxing was the magazine ''[[National Police Gazette]]'', which set up matches and issued championship belts throughout the 1880s. The ''Police Gazette'' sanctioned what is considered the last major bare-knuckle heavyweight world championship, between [[John L. Sullivan]] and [[Jake Kilrain]] on July 8, 1889, with Sullivan emerging as the victor.<ref name="Gazette_4-16-2018">[http://policegazette.us/index.php/2018/04/16/lineal-police-gazette-championships-revived/ National Police Gazette, 16 Apr 2018, p.]</ref><ref name=mastrofist>{{citation |last=Mastro |first=Tim |title=Fistful of Danger |newspaper=[[The News Journal]] |date=13 August 2011 |url=http://www.delawareonline.com/article/20110813/NEWS/108130346/-1/NLETTER01/Fistful-of-danger}}</ref> Since then, other claimants to being sanctioned bare-knuckle championship bouts include the August 5, 2011, match at Fort McDowell Casino on the Yavapai Nation reservation in Arizona. The Native American tribe sanctioned the bout between Rich Stewart of [[New Castle, Delaware]] and [[Bobby Gunn]], with Gunn emerging as the victor.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Woods|first1=Michael|title=Reviving a bygone, bare-knuckle era|url=http://espn.go.com/boxing/story/_/id/6835788/bringing-back-bygone-bare-knuckle-era-boxing|accessdate=June 17, 2015|work=[[ESPN]]|date=August 17, 2011}}</ref> Other noted champions were [[Tom Hyer]], [[Yankee Sullivan]], [[Nonpareil Dempsey]], [[Tom Sharkey]], [[Bob Fitzsimmons]] and [[John Morrissey]].
===Techniques=== While boxing has always included punching, historically it also included grappling techniques like throws, arm locks, chokes as well as kicks. These techniques were banned during the several rule changes which turned classical pugilism, or bare knuckle boxing, into the modern sport of boxing.<ref>{{cite book |last=Lawson |first=Kirk |date=3 June 2011 |title=Banned from Boxing - The forgotten grappling techniques of Classic Pugilism|publisher=lulu.com |isbn=9781257140244}}</ref>
==Irish stand down== "Irish stand down" is a type of traditional bare knuckle fighting where the aspect of maneuvering around the ring is removed, leaving only the less nuanced aspects of punching and "taking" punches. This form of combat was popular in Irish American ghettos in the United States in the late 19th century but was eclipsed in the [[Irish American]] community first by bare knuckle boxing and then later by regulation boxing. The Irish stand down is also known as strap fighting or toe to toe.{{Citation needed|date=June 2018}}
==Modern Bare Knuckle Combat== Modern Bareknuckle Combat, a contemporary form of fist fight, exists on a small scale worldwide, however, recently it has been making its way into the public eye.
In the United States, publicly ticketed events started in the 1990s in the Rocky Mountains, promoted by Jim Smith's Poorboys Professional Boxing. In 2007, Corey Williams and his promotion Who's Your Daddy Productions stepped onto the scene. After years of false starts due to claims that the sport was "brutal" Mr. Williams conducted a medical study proving that bare knuckle combat is in fact safer than its gloved counterpart. Mr. Williams medical research and his publicly ticketed events in Wyoming lead to the States Combat Sports Commission to becoming the first to legitimize the sport of Bare Knuckle Fighting by sanctioning it.
In the United Kingdom, promoters Joe Brown and Jim Freeman Dove (following a visit to America to observe Mr. Williams program) have made strides furthering bare knuckle combat in England. Their promotion, BKB, was the first legal Bare Knuckle promotion in the United Kingdom. There are now several UK promotions successfully conducting shows including UBKB, Rouge Elite and Barefist.
Bare Knuckle Fighting bouts have several changes from traditional gloved boxing rules, notably there is a 20-second count on any knockdown and the fights consist of 3x2 minute rounds, 5x2/7x2 on title fights.
BKB has put on shows all over the United Kingdom including prestigious venues such as the Echo Arena in Liverpool and the O2 Arena in London. BKB have fighters with backgrounds from professional boxing and MMA promotions such as [[Ultimate Fighting Championship|UFC]] and [[Bellator MMA|Bellator]].
==Bare Knuckle Fighting Championship== David Feldman was able to get a fully sanctioned bare knuckle boxing match on Saturday, June 2 in Cheyenne, WY, which was the first-ever legal, regulated, and sanctioned bare-knuckle fight the U.S. in 130 years.<ref>https://www.fastcompany.com/40579781/bareknuckle-fighting-makes-its-fully-legal-return-after-130-years</ref> A second fight was sanctioned in Biloxi, Mississippi on Aug 26, 2018.<ref>http://www.fightsports.tv/bkfc-ceo-on-early-success-of-bare-knuckle-fighting/</ref> A third fight was sanctioned in on October 20, 2018 in Biloxi.<ref> https://www.bjpenn.com/bare-knuckle-boxing/bare-knuckle-fc-3-results-kendall-grove-suffers-brutal-ko-loss-to-marcel-stamps-videos/</ref>

==See also== * [[List of bare-knuckle boxers]] * [[List of bare-knuckle lightweight champions]] * [[Bare Knuckle Boxing Hall of Fame]] * [[London Prize Ring rules]] * [[Russian fist fighting]] * [[Burmese bareknuckle boxing]]

==External links== * [http://www.storyvault.com/video/view/life_as_a_bare_knuckle_boxer Interview with bare knuckle boxer from the 1950s] * [https://www.bareknuckle.tv Bare Knuckle Fighting Championship] (USA-based organization) * [http://www.bkbworld.co.uk Bare Knuckle Boxing] (UK-based organization) * [http://www.wbba.com World Bareknuckle Boxing Association] (USA-based organization) * [http://pugilism.org A site dedicated to teaching Historical Bare Knuckle Boxing] * [http://bareknuckleboxing.freeforums.net A free site dedicated to the Art]

revision.text:
{{Infobox National Paralympic Committee | title = Cameroonian National Paralympic Committee | logo = | size = | country = Cameroon | code = CMR | created =August 21, 2011 | recognized = [[International Paralympic Committee]] (IPC)
[[Government of Cameroon]] | association =Cameroonian National Paralympic Committee | headquarters = [[Yaounde]] | president = [[Jean Jacques Ndoudoumou]] | secretary general =[[Etienne Songa Bidjocka]] | website = [http://www.camerounparalympique.org/ camerounparalympique.org] }} '''Cameroonian National Paralympic Committee''' ({{lang-fr|Comité national paralympique camerounais}}, '''CNPC''') is the primary [[Sports governing body|body]] in [[Cameroon]] for the promotion of sports for people with disabilities. It has four member organizations: [[Cameroonian Sports Federation for the Visually Impaired]] (FECASDEV), [[Cameroonian Sports Federation for the Physically Disabled]] (FECASDEP), [[Cameroonian Federation of Sports the Intellectually Disabled]] (FECASDI) and the [[Cameroonian Sports Federation for the Deaf]] (FECASSO). The President of the Cameroonian Paralympic Committee is [[Jean Jacques Ndoudoumou]]. The organization has four vice presidents, who all serve as the presidents of CNPC's member organizations. The CNPC's history dates to the early 2010s, following a period where the country's previous [[National Paralympic Committee]] (NPC) had poor relations with the [[government of Cameroon]] and the [[International Paralympic Committee]] (IPC). After the CNPC was formally created and recognized by law, the created a strategic plan and set about capacity building activities. The CNPC has some funding via grants and sponsorship. Future success for the CNPC is perceived by insiders as being dependent on government support for the Paralympic movement in Cameroon. == Governance == The CNPC has four member organizations. These are [[Cameroonian Sports Federation for the Visually Impaired]] (FECASDEV),The name of the organization in French is, ''{{Lang|fr|Fédération camerounaise de Football (Fécafoot)}}''. the [[Cameroonian Sports Federation for the Physically Disabled]] (FECASDEP),The name of the organization in French is, ''{{Lang|fr|Fédération Camerounaise de Sports pour Déficients Physiques}}''. [[Cameroonian Federation of Sports the Intellectually Disabled]] (FECASDI)The name of the organization in French is, ''{{Lang|fr|Federation Camerounaise Des Sports Pour Deficients Intellectuals}}''. and the [[Cameroonian Sports Federation for the Deaf]] (FECASSO).The name of the organization in French is, ''{{Lang|fr|Fédération Camerounaise de Sports pour Sourds}}''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.camerounparalympique.org/notre-organisation/|title=Notre Organisation - International Paralympic Committee|last=|first=|date=2016|website=Comité National Paralympique Camerounais (CNPC)|publisher=Comité National Paralympique Camerounais (CNPC)|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 5, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018205257/http://www.camerounparalympique.org/notre-organisation/|archivedate=October 18, 2016|df=}} The President of the Cameroonian Paralympic Committee is [[Jean Jacques Ndoudoumou]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.paralympic.org/cameroon|title=Cameroon - National Paralympic Committee|last=|first=|date=|website=International Paralympic Committee|publisher=International Paralympic Committee|access-date=October 2, 2016}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.cameroon-info.net/article/cameroun-sportjeux-paralympiques-le-cameroun-present-a-rio-avec-un-seul-athlete-269625.html|title=Sport/Jeux paralympiques: Le Cameroun présent à Rio avec un seul athlète|last=Ngon|first=Otric|date=September 7, 2016|website=Cameroun-Info.Net: Le Portail du Cameroun|publisher=Cameroon-Info.Net|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 2, 2016}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.cameroonconcordnews.com/paralympic-games-cameroon-in-rio-with-one-athlete-7-man-delegation/|title=Paralympic Games: Cameroon in Rio with one athlete, 7 man delegation|last=Akana|first=Rita|date=September 7, 2016|website=Cameroon Concord News|publisher=Cameroon Concord News|access-date=October 3, 2016}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.camerounlink.com/mobile/?SessionID=A2YF3QCB2QGAK7WPSMK7WTVGRV1IUK&cl1=&cl2=&bnid=2&nid=95276&cat=0&kat=0|title=Brésil: le Cameroun aligne un athlète aux Jeux paralympiques|last=Remadji|first=Victoria|date=September 9, 2016|work=Cameroun Link|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 7, 2016|via=}} Ndoudoumou has held this position since the organization was formally created on August 21, 2011. Prior to taking on this role, he was the General Director of the Agence de régulation des marchés publics (ARMP).{{Cite news|url=https://www.237online.com/article-19954-quatre-nouvelles-federations-sportives-bientot-au-cameroun.html|title=Quatre nouvelles fédérations sportives bientôt au Cameroun|last=|first=|date=March 18, 2011|work=|publisher=237online.com|newspaper=|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 7, 2016|via=}} He also served as the President of the Cameroon branch of the [[World Association for Advocacy and Solidarity of Albinos]] (ASMODISA).The name of the organization in French is, ''{{Lang|fr|antenne du Cameroun de l'Association mondiale pour la défense des intérêts et la solidarité des albinos}}''. He got he role following the elections for the position in August 2011, winning a four-year term after collecting 84 of the 87 available votes where he was the only candidate running.{{Cite web|url=http://french.peopledaily.com.cn/Sports/7577489.html|title=Cameroun : élection du président du comité national paralympique-Le Quotidien du Peuple en ligne|last=|first=|date=August 23, 2011|website=People's Daily (China)|publisher=|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 8, 2016}}{{Cite web|url=http://fr.cntv.cn/20110822/105271.shtml|title=CCTV-Cameroun : les statuts du comité national paralympique adoptés|last=Xinhua|first=|date=August 22, 2011|website=CNTV|publisher=|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 8, 2016}} Ndoudoumou had been accused of mismanagement while serving as the General Director of the Regulatory Board for Public Procurement (ARMP)The name of the organization in French is, ''{{Lang|fr|Agence de régulation des marchés publics}}''. before he was fired from his position.{{Cite web|url=http://www.africapresse.com/jean-jacques-ndoudoumou-je-ne-suis-pas-coupable-de-detournement/|title=Jean-Jacques Ndoudoumou, "je ne suis pas coupable de détournement" {{!}} Actualite en Afrique et Cameroun|last=Le Jour|first=|date=March 28, 2013|website=Africa Presse|publisher=Africa Presse|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 8, 2016}} Those same elections also saw [[Ebot Ntui]] become a Vice President. He had previously served as the ministre chargé de missions à la Présidence de la République. [[Etienne Songa]] has been CNPC's Secretary General since 2009.{{Cite web|url=https://www.paralympic.org/news/ipc-launches-websites-cameroon-and-panama|title=IPC Launches Websites for Cameroon and Panama|last=|first=|date=July 26, 2012|website=International Paralympic Committee|publisher=|access-date=October 2, 2016}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.afrik.com/article26776.html|title=Jeux paralympiques : le manque de moyens décourage les athlètes africains|last=Baldé|first=Assanatou|date=August 29, 2012|website=afrik.com|publisher=|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 2, 2016}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/fr/20120821-parcours-combattant-athletes-handisport-africains-cameroun-burundi-pistorius-londres-jeux-paralympiques|title=Les Jeux paralympiques, une course d'obstacles pour les athlètes africains|last=Trouillard|first=Stéphanie|date=August 21, 2012|website=France 24|publisher=France 24|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 2, 2016}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.cameroonvoice.com/news/article-sport-495.html|title=Comité international paralympique : Le Cameroun menacé de radiation|last=Biwol|first=Ateba|date=July 23, 2009|website=Cameroon Voice|publisher=Cameroon Voice|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 2, 2016}} In October 2014, Songa traveled to Brazzaville, Congo to give a presentation to the Congolese National Paralympic Committee (French: Comité national paralympique congolais).{{Cite web|url=http://www.lasemaineafricaine.net/index.php/sports/10219-developpement-du-para-sport-le-comite-paralympique-decline-sa-vision|title=lasemaineafricaine - Développement du para-sport : Le comité paralympique décline sa vision|last=OKEMBA|first=Grévy Joël|date=October 17, 2014|website=lasemaineafricaine|publisher=lasemaineafricaine|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 9, 2016}} The organization has four vice presidents, who all serve as the presidents of CNPC's member organizations. These vice-presidents include FECASDI's [[Jean-Marie Aléokol Mabiemé]], FECASDEP's [[Herve Guy Ngoyo Ngon]], FECASDEV's [[Norbert Tsoungui]] and FECASSO's [[Pierre Valery Pemha]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.cameroonvoice.com/news/article-sport-7852.html|title=Jeux paralympiques. Vers une nouvelle participation foireuse du Cameroun|last=Tchapmi|first=Christian TCHAPMI|date=August 17, 2012|website=Cameroon Voice|publisher=Le Messager|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 9, 2016}} Other officers and key organizational personnel include Vice President [[Ogork Ntui Obot]], Chief Financial Officer [[Christophe Ampoam]], Deputy Secretary General [[Nazaire Ubalt Olinga]], Deputy Financial Officer [[Jules Benjamin Mateck Ma Bilolo’o]], Athlete Representative [[Constance Nchifi]] and Coach Representative [[Martin Luther Adibita]]. The organization's mission is to develop partnerships and mobilize resources in Cameroon to support the country's para-sportspeople.{{Cite web|url=http://www.camerounparalympique.org/notre-mission/|title=Notre Mission - International Paralympic Committee|last=Comité national paralympique camerounais (Cnpc)|first=|date=2016|website=Comité national paralympique camerounais (Cnpc)|publisher=International Paralympic Committee|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 5, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161118191452/http://www.camerounparalympique.org/notre-mission/#|archive-date=2016-11-18|dead-url=yes|df=}} They have a vision of developing para-sports in Cameroon to assist in creating a society that is more inclusive and equitable for people with disabilities.{{Cite web|url=http://www.camerounparalympique.org/notre-vision/|title=Notre Vision - International Paralympic Committee|last=Comité national paralympique camerounais (Cnpc)|first=|date=2016|website=Comité national paralympique camerounais (Cnpc)|publisher=International Paralympic Committee|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 5, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161118181223/http://www.camerounparalympique.org/notre-vision/#|archive-date=2016-11-18|dead-url=yes|df=}} They are supposed to be apolitical in all their dealings.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/Issues/Disability/PoliticalParticipation/States/Cameroon.pdf|title=Response du Government sur la mis en ceuvre et l'application de la resolution 16/15 du conseil des droits de l'homme relative aux droits des peronnes handicapees|last=Permanent Mission of the Republic of Cameroon to the United Nations|first=|date=November 2011|website=Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR)|publisher=Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR)|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 9, 2016}} The organization is headquartered in [[Yaounde]]. == History == Prior to the creation of the CNPC, the NPC for Cameroon was the [[Cameroonian Sports Federation for People with Disabilities]] (FECASH).{{Cite web|url=http://www.news.mboa.info/sport-pour-tous/fr/content/actualite/15372,jeux-paralympiques-le-cameroun-absent-a-beijing/0,0/4389.html|title=Sport pour tous - Jeux paralympiques : Le Cameroun absent à Beijing|last=|first=|date=September 9, 2008|website=Mboa.info|publisher=Mboa.info|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 7, 2016}} The Federation had a number of issues including lack of organizational status, potentially not being recognized by the Cameroonian government and by the IPC, and claims of several NPCs all claiming to represent Cameroon being in existence.{{Cite web|url=http://www.news.mboa.info/sport-pour-tous/fr/content/actualite/57841,jeux-paralympiques-2008-le-cameroun-absent-pour-desordre/0,0/4389.html|title=Sport pour tous - Jeux paralympiques 2008 : Le Cameroun absent pour désordre|last=|first=|date=September 11, 2008|website=Mboa.info|publisher=Mboa.info|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 7, 2016}} Cameroon's NPC had also been repeatedly suspended by the IPC as a result of problems related to the Ministry of Sports and the CNPC, with the IPC recognizing the CNPC but the Government of Cameroon not recognizing the CNPC as the country's NPC, and because the NPC had failed to pay IPC membership fees.{{Cite web|url=http://www.news.mboa.info/athletisme/fr/content/actualite/58318,jeux-paralympiques-2008-doutes-sur-la-participation-camerounaise/0,0/8493.html|title=Athlétisme - Jeux paralympiques 2008 : Doutes sur la participation camerounaise|last=|first=|date=August 5, 2008|website=Mboa.info|publisher=Mboa.info|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 8, 2016}}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{Cite web|url=http://www.yanous.com/pratique/sports-loisirs/sportsloisirs100416.html|title=Handisports et loisirs : Handisport au Cameroun.|last=Bih|first=Muluh Hilda|last2=Soué|first2=Emilienne|date=April 2010|website=Yanous!|publisher=Yanous!|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 6, 2016}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.news.mboa.info/jeux-olympiques/fr/content/actualite/15807,jeux-paralympiques-2008-pourquoi-le-cameroun-est-absent.html|title=Jeux Olympiques - Jeux paralympiques 2008 : Pourquoi le Cameroun est absent|last=|first=|date=September 9, 2008|website=Mboa.info|publisher=Mboa.info|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 7, 2016}} One suspension occurred in 2003, and another from 2005 that included 2008, 2009 and 2010. Law No. 2011-18 of 15 July 2011 related to the organization and promotion of Physical and Sporting Activities created by force of law the government recognized Cameroonian National Paralympic Committee, addressing earlier issues related to lack of government recognition of a National Paralympic Committee.{{Cite book|url=http://www.barreaucameroun.org/fr/pdf/jo/JO%20-%202011%20-%20n%C2%B03%20special.pdf|title=Consulter - Ordre des Avocats au Barreau du Cameroun|last=Biya|first=Paul|publisher=|date=July 15, 2011|isbn=|location=Yaounde|pages=7–39|language=fr-FR|via=}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.minas.cm/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=156&Itemid=182&lang=fr&limitstart=1|title=Protection des Personnes Handicapées - Page 2|last=Ministère des Affaires Sociales (MINAS)|first=|date=|website=Ministère des Affaires Sociales (MINAS)|publisher=Ministère des Affaires Sociales (MINAS)|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 3, 2016}} FECASH had been dissolved by the same law. The law recognized and made FECASDEV, FECASDEP, FECASDI and FECASSO as four member federations of the CNPC.{{Cite web|url=http://www.yanous.com/news/rdpresse/rdpresse1103.html|title=Revue de presse internationale du handicap : Mars 2011.|last=|first=|date=March 2011|website=Yanous!|publisher=Yanous!|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 6, 2016}} Following the formal legislative creation of the CNPC in 2011, the organization and its four new member organizations had 30 days to hold elections for the boards of these organizations. Candidates to head the CNPC were already known prior to the election announcement, with FECASH Chairman Abeng Mbozo'o having bowed out of contention before then. The process leading to the CNPC's creation began in March 2011. The organization changed their name to "Comité National Paralympique Camerounais (CNPC)" on August 21, 2011.{{Cite web|url=http://www.camerounparalympique.org/download/clientfiles/files/PLAN%20STRATEGIQUE%20CNPC%202013-2016.doc|title=Plan Strategique 2013-2016 due Comité National Paralympique Camerounais (CNPC)|last=CNPC|first=|date=2013|website=Comité National Paralympique Camerounais (CNPC)|publisher=International Paralympic Committee|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 5, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160329202140/http://www.camerounparalympique.org/download/clientfiles/files/PLAN%20STRATEGIQUE%20CNPC%202013-2016.doc#|archive-date=2016-03-29|dead-url=yes|df=}} The name change and changes in the law signaled major change in the organization. In December 2011 in [[Beijing]], the CNPC participated in their first IPC Congress. The changes normalized the CNPC's relationship with the International Paralympic Committee, and the country's athletes were then eligible to compete in some competitions because of the Paralympic Solidarity program. The CNPC developed a strategic plan for period of 2013 to 2016. This plan was designed to prepare the country for the 2016 Summer Paralympics. It had seven major objectives. These included improving organizational structure, developing human and institutional resources, sustaining and improving para-sports physical infrastructure and sporting equipment, increase awareness of para-sports, creating athlete development pathways, and ensure Cameroonian participation in national and international events. The NPC had their first website in 2012 as part of efforts by the International Paralympic Committee to increase the digital presence for its member nations. This website was designed with the goal of providing information for sportspeople on the local level all the way up to the elite level of Paralympic sport in Cameroon. The website was in French.{{Cite web|url=https://www.paralympic.org/news/ipc-launches-first-official-website-npc-el-salvador|title=IPC launches first official website for NPC El Salvador|last=IPC|first=|date=July 9, 2013|website=International Paralympic Committee|publisher=International Paralympic Committee|access-date=October 2, 2016}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1010546/ipc-launches-new-websites-for-cameroon-and-panama|title=IPC launches new websites for Cameroon and Panama|last=Gold|first=David|date=July 27, 2012|website=Inside the Games|publisher=Inside the Games|access-date=October 2, 2016}} In December 2012, the NPC participated in an athletics (track and field) training seminar organized by the IPC in Dakar, Senegal for French speaking African countries.{{Cite web|url=http://www.camerounparalympique.org/projets/|title=Projets - International Paralympic Committee|last=Comité National Paralympique Camerounais (CNPC)|first=|date=2016|website=Comité National Paralympique Camerounais (CNPC)|publisher=International Paralympic Committee|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 6, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406001610/http://www.camerounparalympique.org/projets/#|archive-date=2016-04-06|dead-url=yes|df=}} Jean-Marie Aléokol Mabiemé co-wrote a guide called, "Guide du Sport pour Personne vivant avec un Handicap". In 2014, he was a trainer at a CONFEJES event in Yaoundé organized by the Ministry of Sports and Physical Education and the Paralympic Committee of Cameroon. Twenty sports administrators from four Central African countries participated in the conference.{{Cite news|url=http://www.confejes.org/formation-des-formateurs-du-sport-pour-les-personnes-vivant-avec-un-handicap/|title=Formation des formateurs du sport pour les personnes vivant avec un handicap - Confejes|last=|first=|date=July 17, 2014|work=|newspaper=Confejes|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 12, 2016|via=}} In 2014, the NPC hosted a capacity building workshop in coordination with the [[IPC Academy]]. Capacity building inside NPCs like Cameroon was part of the IPC's Strategic Plan to improve NPC capacity and efficiency in governance, management, leadership and sport promotion in member countries. Other countries that held similar workshops in 2013 and 2014 included [[Ghana]], [[Cape Verde]], [[Ethiopia]], [[Ghana]], [[Haiti]], [[Liberia]], [[Puerto Rico]], [[Serbia]], [[Seychelles]], and [[Vanuatu]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.paralympic.org/news/npcs-positively-progress-towards-developing-para-sport|title=NPCs positively progress towards developing para-sport|last=IPC|first=|date=May 21, 2014|website=International Paralympic Committee|publisher=International Paralympic Committee|access-date=October 2, 2016}} == Funding == One of the sources for funding of the disability sports movement in Cameroon has been [[Agitos Foundation]] grants. In 2014, the NPC received a grant to promote Paralympic Sport in the country.{{Cite web|url=https://www.paralympic.org/video/29-agitos-foundation-grows-paralympic-movement-globally|title=29 Agitos Foundation grows Paralympic Movement globally|last=|first=|date=2014|website=International Paralympic Committee|publisher=International Paralympic Committee|access-date=October 2, 2016}} The NPC received a grant of €800 ahead of the Rio Games to promote Paralympic and para-sports before, during and after the Paralympic Games. This grant was part of the Organisational Capacity Programme (OCP). The money was used by Cameroon to host a come and try it event in July 2016, and used to get additional media coverage from radio and television news.{{Cite web|url=https://www.paralympic.org/news/countries-receive-support-awareness-campaigns|title=Countries to receive support for awareness campaigns|last=|first=|date=June 17, 2016|website=International Paralympic Committee|publisher=International Paralympic Committee|access-date=October 2, 2016}} In June 2016, the CNPC signed a sponsorship agreement with MACRON to provide the kit for the Cameroon team at the 2016 Summer Paralympics. The CNPC viewed this historic sponsorship deal as important towards the continued professionalization of Paralympic sport in Cameroon.{{Cite web|url=http://www.camerounparalympique.org/centre-de-presse/news/|title=News News|last=Comité National Paralympique Camerounais (CNPC)|first=|date=2016|website=Comité National Paralympique Camerounais (CNPC)|publisher=International Paralympic Committee|language=fr-FR|access-date=October 6, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160329202148/http://www.camerounparalympique.org/centre-de-presse/news/#|archive-date=2016-03-29|dead-url=yes|df=}} Success going forward in the Paralympic movement is perceived by those involved with para-sports in Cameroon as being dependent on the government for continued and increased support. == See also == * [[Cameroon at the Paralympics]] == Translations == {{reflist|group=translations}} == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == {{Portal|Paralympics|Cameroon}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20161013112520/http://www.camerounparalympique.org/ Official website] {{Disability sports in Cameroon}} {{Sports governing bodies in Cameroon}} {{African Paralympic Committee}} [[Category:National Paralympic Committees]] [[Category:Cameroon at the Paralympics]] [[Category:Sports governing bodies in Cameroon]] [[Category:Disabled sports organizations]] [[Category:2011 establishments in Cameroon]] [[Category:Sports organisations established in 2011]]

Dating maintenance tags: {{Citation needed}}
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=July 2013}} '''Danish Longball''' (also known as ''Swedick longball'') is a [[Bat-and-ball games|bat-and-ball]] game founded in [[Denmark]]. It is popular in some [[British people|British]] secondary schools {{Citation needed|date=October 2018}}, and is also played recreationally by [[scouts]], the [[Air Training Corps]] and by the [[Royal Navy|British Navy]] and [[Australian Navy]]. It is also a popular sport at U.S. [[summer camp]]s.<ref>{{cite web|last=Butler|first=Joy|title=Danish Longball: A Novel game to introduce the batting/ fielding games category|url=http://ubcpete.files.wordpress.com/2008/07/danish-longball.pdf|publisher=UBC PETE Association|accessdate=5 July 2013}}</ref>
==Play== Danish Longball can be described as a hybrid of [[baseball]] and [[cricket]]. There is a modern variant that is based on [[football]]<ref name=21st>{{cite web|title=Danish Longball Football |url=http://21stbournemouth.org.uk/games/?p=93 |publisher=21st Group Games Database |accessdate=5 July 2013 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> too. Each team takes turns batting and fielding. In British secondary schools in particular, an element of [[dodgeball]] is incorporated, with a player being "out" if he or she is hit with the ball (outside the safety zone) below the head whilst aiming to get a run.
===Teams and positions=== Players are split into two teams, a batting team and a balling team. The batting team waits behind the batting goal ready to bat. The balling team is spread behind the batting goal and the safe goal ready to field.
===Field of play=== The batting field has two parts: Inside and outside a square (or circle). Fielders can position themselves inside or outside the square. The fielder who fields the ball cannot move with it rather they must pass it to another fielder in a better position to hit the runner.
===Equipment=== *ball, usually a [[tennis ball]] *bat/tennis racket *optional safety pads
===Rules=== The bowler pitches the ball to the batter, who must use their bat to hit the ball. The ball must be hit within the field of play – the square. The ball must hit the ground at least once before it bounces or rolls off the field. The batter must then run to the other side of the square to a "safe zone". The runner may rest in safety, but to earn a "run" they must make it safely back to the original side of the square without getting out. Each side bats its entire line-up. Five rounds of play are recommended.
When played in Britain it is usually an alternative to Cricket, so timed [[innings]] may be used along with a set of stumps (though usually not a cricket ball, as the risk of injury is significantly raised rather than a tennis ball).
A player is out if * The hit is caught by one of the fielding team * the ball does not touch the ground of the marked area * or if the fielders hits a runner outside the safe-zones with the ball. * he/she runs outside the side lines of the square.
A variant of the above is sometimes used: if a fielder hits a runner with the ball outside the safe-zones then the entire batting team is out.
== Winning the game== The winning team is the one that scores the most runs.
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{italic title}} {{refimprove|date=July 2011}} :''This article refers to a play. For the book by [[Shalom Auslander]] see ''[[Foreskin's Lament: A Memoir]]''.'' '''''Foreskin's Lament''''' is a landmark play in the history of New Zealand theatre.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://teara.govt.nz/en/ephemera/43968/foreskins-lament-1981|title=Foreskin's lament, 1981|last=Taonga|first=New Zealand Ministry for Culture and Heritage Te Manatu|website=teara.govt.nz|language=en|access-date=2018-04-20}}</ref> It was the breakthrough play for its writer, [[Greg McGee]], and was initially workshopped at the New Zealand Playwrights' Conference in Wellington in 1980, and has since become a staple of New Zealand theatre. Being produced as it was immediately before and during the social unrest of the [[1981 Springbok Tour]] of New Zealand,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=11030|title=Nothing lamentable in play's latest outing|date=2000-06-30|work=NZ Herald|access-date=2018-04-20|language=en-NZ|issn=1170-0777}}</ref> it hit a nerve with the public and was named Best New Zealand Play of 1981.
The play is a drama set in a [[rugby union]] changing room after a practice, and at an after-match party. The captain is kicked in the head off-stage at the beginning of the first act, and again during the game between acts. He dies in hospital during the second act. The theme is the conflict between fair play and winning at all costs, and the non-conformist lead character Foreskin's struggle to reconcile his university liberal values with those of his rugby-playing conservative mates.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/sunday-star-times/features/profiles/549211/Greg-McGee-and-telling-tales|title=Greg McGee and telling tales|website=Stuff|language=en|access-date=2018-04-20}}</ref> The play ends with Foreskin directly addressing the audience in a monologue - or rather interrogation - filled with rugby allusions, questioning their own values, ending with the repeated question, "Whaddarya?" (usually used in New Zealand to question someone's masculinity). Early performances left audiences in stunned silence. In some productions Foreskin undresses during the lament and finishes nude.
In New Zealand a rugby union player is an everyman, and the game and play present a model of society. Set in 1976, it looks forward to the 1981 Springbok Tour. It has been suggested {{by whom?|date=May 2018}} the misnamed character "Clean" was based on [[Rob Muldoon]]. The script was updated after the 1981 tour and was later heavily revised by the author for filming as ''[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0382303/ Skin and Bones]''.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.nzonair.govt.nz/news_detail.php?pid=874&sid=800 New Zealand On Air] *[http://www.playmarket.org.nz/about_profiles.php?id=102&l=M Greg McGee] *[http://www.nzherald.co.nz/topic/story.cfm?c_id=544&objectid=11030 Review of 1999 production]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Formula One|lists}} '''Formula One sponsorship liveries''' have been used since the late 1960s, replacing the previously used [[list of international auto racing colors|national colours]]. With [[sponsor (commercial)|sponsors]] becoming more important with the rising costs in Formula One, many teams wanted to be able to display the logos of their sponsors as clearly as possible.
The liveries are usually changed for every season in the sport, marking the marketing ideas of the sponsors. Many teams keep some consistency over the years however, like the red colour of Ferrari, which has its origin in a shade of red known as [[rosso corsa]] being the national racing colour of Italy. Tobacco and alcohol advertising was common in motorsport, however as bans spread throughout the world teams used an alternate livery which alluded to the tobacco or alcohol sponsor, or entirely eliminated their name when in nations with a ban – this is now only seen on Ferrari's Marlboro sponsored vehicles – where the sponsor is technically banned from advertising in all host nations. At historical events, cars are allowed to use the livery which was used when the car was actively competing.<ref>Appendix K to the International sporting code, section 2.1.10</ref>
==AGS== [[Automobiles Gonfaronnaises Sportives]] (AGS) were founded in [[Gonfaron]], France, in the late 1960s, but only entered Formula One in 1986.

International |- |[[1989 Formula One season|1989]] |White |Faure |[[Camel (cigarette)|Camel]], [[Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company|Goodyear]], LM |- |[[1990 Formula One season|1990]] | |Ted Lapidus |Goodyear |- |[[1991 Formula One season|1991]] White |Blue |Red, Yellow |Paolo Fiore |Filling, mmta, Goodyear, Bburago |} <center> <gallery> File:AGS JH23 Formula 1 Car.jpg|Philippe Streiff's AGSJH23 from the 1988 Season at Silverstone File:AGSJH23.jpg|An AGS JH23 from the 1988 Formula One Season </gallery> </center>
==Alfa Romeo== [[Alfa Romeo in Formula One|Alfa Romeo]] was a Formula One constructor between 1950 and 1951, and again between 1979 and 1985. In 1950–1951 and 1979 the team used the [[rosso corsa]] (racing red) national color of Italy. In 1980 they switched to a livery sponsored by [[Phillip Morris International|Phillip Morris']] [[Marlboro (cigarette)|Marlboro]] cigarette brand. In 1984 the Italian clothing brand [[Benetton Group|Benetton]] took over Alfa Romeo's livery sponsorship, which they held until the withdrawal of Alfa Romeo from Formula One at the end of 1985.

==Arrows== Starting in the 1970s and going for decades until ending in mid-2002, [[Arrows Grand Prix International|Arrows]], that was known as Footwork for a few years in the 1990s, had quite distinctive liveries, like the unusual Ruffles sponsorship in Footwork, an all-black car in the 1998 season, and an orange car in its final years.

==Benetton== [[Benetton Formula|Benetton Formula Ltd.]], commonly referred to simply as Benetton, was a Formula One constructor that participated from 1986 to 2001. The team was owned by the Benetton family who run a worldwide chain of clothing stores of the same name. In 2000 the team was purchased by Renault, but competed as Benetton for the 2001 season. In 2002 the team became [[Renault F1]]. From the 1991 to 1993, [[Camel (cigarette)|Camel]] sponsored the Benetton team, but, from the 1994 to 2001 the main sponsor was [[Mild Seven]].

==BMS Scuderia Italia==
In its Dallara years, Scuderia Italia raced with a livery slightly similar to Ferrari (rosso corsa with white details and black wings), but prior to the absorption by Minardi in 1993, when raced with Lola cars, had a white livery with red and yellow flames.

==BMW Sauber== After having been an engine supplier in the 1980s and again since 2000, [[BMW]] entered Formula One with a works team of its own in [[2006 Formula One season|2006]] after buying the Swiss Formula One constructor [[Sauber]]. Although the cars had many sponsorship logos on them, the main pattern was based on the traditional [[BMW Motorsport]] team colours of white with light blue, dark blue and a little red (in an almost purple shade). White is also the original [[List of international auto racing colors|national racing colour]] of Germany, while white and blue are the colours of [[Bavaria]] and of BMW itself.
On 27 November 2009, BMW agreed to sell the team back to its original founder, [[Peter Sauber]].<ref name="telegraph.co.uk">''[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/motorsport/formulaone/bmwsauber/6669774/Formula-One-team-BMW-agree-deal-with-Peter-Sauber.html Formula One team BMW agree deal with Peter Sauber]'' telegraph.co.uk. Retrieved 3 February 2010.</ref> The [[2010 Formula One season]] marked Sauber's return as an independent constructor.

==Brabham== Prior to sponsorships, Brabham raced in turquoise with a gold band running across the car. This later changed to green and gold, the racing colours of Australia. In 1975 and 1976, Brabham received sponsorship from [[Martini & Rossi|Martini]]; in 1976 the color scheme changed from white to red with light blue trim. The primary sponsor changed to [[Parmalat]] in 1978, with the cars retaining a variant of the same red and blue colors. With the team's switch to BMW engines in 1982, the new livery consisted of a clean dark blue and white with a stylized BMW "kidney grille" on the nose. This scheme was retained throughout the BMW years, even through a sponsorship change to [[Olivetti]] in 1984, until 1989. (This unusual representation of the engine supplier, specifically BMW, in the color scheme was revived by Williams when they debuted their own BMW cars in 2000.) In 1989, Brabham signed with Bioptron, a brand of [[Philip Zepter|Zepter International]], which continued until the team was bought by Middlebridge Group. Since then, it was sponsored by many Japanese companies like Garage Italiya, a company that imports Italian cars in Japan, Autobacs, Nippon Shinpan, and Mitsukoshi. Prior the swansong of Brabham in 1992, the team raced in blue and pink livery of the Japanese metal group [[Seikima-II]].

==Brawn GP== After Honda pulled out of F1 at the end of 2008, team boss Ross Brawn struggled to find a buyer to save the team, eventually buying it himself. A lack of sponsors resulted in the white livery, with flashes of bright yellow and black. Towards the end of the season, the team arranged one-race sponsor deals with a variety of major local companies, including [[Canon (company)|Canon]], [[Mapfre]], [[Itaipava]] and [[Qtel]].
[[Brawn GP]] dominated the early part of the 2009 season, with Jenson Button winning six of the first seven races. As other teams improved their cars Brawn struggled for pace, but still recorded several podiums during the rest of the year. Their strong start and consistent finish was enough to secure the Constructors World Championship at the first (and only) attempt, as well as the drivers title with Jenson Button. At the end of the season, the team was purchased by engine suppliers Mercedes-Benz, marking the return of the Silver Arrows after 55 years.

==British American Racing== [[British American Racing]] competed in Formula One from 1999 to 2005. The name of the team was taken from [[British American Tobacco]] which provided the main sponsorship and was livery sponsor through two of its main cigarette brands. In their debut season, the team wished to have its two cars painted in different liveries (one 555, the other Lucky Strike), but this was forbidden by the rules. So the team decided on a unique two-sided design, with the blue 555 livery of the right side of the car, and the red and white Luckies livery on the left and a zipper design on the middle.

==Caterham== The [[Team Lotus (2010–11)|Lotus team, which made its début in 2010]], was renamed to [[Caterham F1]] in {{F1|2012}}. It was formally from Malaysia but still had a livery dominated by [[British racing green]], like the old Lotus team had for many years.

==Ferrari== In keeping with their Italian roots, [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] has always kept a red colour in the tradition of [[rosso corsa]], the national racing colour of Italy, except for two races in 1964 when Enzo Ferrari let his cars enter by [[North American Racing Team|NART]] in American blue and white colours to protest against Italian racing authorities. Over the years, rosso corsa has been combined with white parts and with various sponsorship schemes, but Ferrari has never fully let their cars be dominated by the sponsorship livery like many other teams have. This changed in the 1990s when Ferrari replaced their traditional rosso corsa colour with a "Marlboro red" which is noticeably lighter; this colour remains despite the ban on tobacco sponsorship.

<center> <gallery> File:Bandini, Lorenzo - Ferrari-12-Zylinder 1966.jpg|With the exception of the 1964 [[1964 United States Grand Prix|United States]] and [[1964 Mexican Grand Prix|Mexican]] Grands Prix, Ferrari has always raced in the Italian national racing colour of [[rosso corsa]]. This is [[Lorenzo Bandini]] driving the [[Ferrari 312]] at the [[1966 German Grand Prix]]. File:LaudaNiki19760731Ferrari312T2.jpg|[[Niki Lauda]] driving the [[Ferrari 312T]] at the [[1976 German Grand Prix]]. By this time, the Ferrari livery included the logos of team suppliers such as [[Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company|Goodyear]] and [[Agip]]. File:Gilles Villeneuve 1979 Imola.jpg|[[Gilles Villeneuve]] sitting beside the [[Ferrari 312T]] at the [[1979 San Marino Grand Prix]]. Just like in previous seasons, the Scuderia Ferrari livery included Goodyear and Agip as their sponsors File:Alboreto Ferrari 126C4 1984 Dallas F1.jpg|Michele Alboreto racing for Ferrari at the 1984 Dallas GP File:Alboreto 1985-08-02.jpg|Alboreto racing for Ferrari in 1985 File:Alboreto at 1986 Italian Grand Prix.jpg|Alboreto racing for Ferrari in 1986 File:Michele Alboreto 1988 Canada.jpg|Alboreto racing for Ferrari in 1988 File:Ferrari 641 MOMA 2.jpg|Alain Prost's Ferrari 641 from the 1990 season in display File:Prost monaco91.jpg|[[Alain Prost]] driving the [[Ferrari 642]] at the [[1991 Monaco Grand Prix]], with a largely unchanged livery from 1976. File:Ferrari F93A Goodwood 2008.jpg|Alesi's Ferrari F93A being demonstrated at The Goodwood Festival of Speed in 2008 File:Ferrari 412Ts 1994.jpg|Until 2000, Ferrari used the barcode in countries where tobacco advertising is not allowed, like Great Britain and France. These are Jean Alesi and Gerhard Berger at the 1994 British Grand Prix File:Jean Alesi Ferrari 1995.jpg|By {{F1|1995}}, the team had received primary sponsorship from [[Marlboro (cigarette)|Marlboro]]. This is [[Jean Alesi]] driving the [[Ferrari 412T2]] at that year's [[1995 Canadian Grand Prix|Canadian Grand Prix]] to win his first Grand Prix victory. File:Ferrari Formel 1.jpg|Michael Schumacher's low-nosed Ferrari F310 from 1996. File:Ferrari F310 1996 Schumacher.jpg|The high-nosed 1996 Ferrari F310 in display.
