File:Ferrari world-abu dhabi-2011 (20).JPG|A 2000 [[Ferrari F1-2000]] in non-tobacco livery in display. File:Rubens Barrichello 2000 Belgian.jpg|Rubens Barrichello driving for Ferrari at 2000 Belgian GP File:Michael Schumacher 2001 Canada.jpg|[[Michael Schumacher]] driving the [[Ferrari F2001|Scuderia Ferrari F2001]] at the [[2001 Canadian Grand Prix]], showing sponsorship from Marlboro, [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell]], [[Fiat]], and Magneti Marelli File:Schumacher Ferrari F2001 at Laguna Seca.jpg|A Ferrari F2001 in non-tobacco livery being driven in Laguna Seca File:Mschumacher 2002.jpg|[[Michael Schumacher]] driving the [[Ferrari F2002|Scuderia Ferrari F2002]] at the [[2002 French Grand Prix]], showing sponsorship from [[Vodafone]], [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell]], and the white space replacing Marlboro at North American and most European races. File:Barrichello 2003.jpg|[[Rubens Barrichello]] driving the [[Ferrari F2002|Scuderia Ferrari F2002]] at the [[2002 United States Grand Prix]], showing sponsorship from [[Vodafone]], [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell]], and the white space replacing Marlboro at North American and most European races. File:Michael Schumacher Ferrari 2004.jpg|Schumacher at the [[2004 United States Grand Prix]] driving the [[Ferrari F2004|Scuderia Ferrari F2004]] with completely white spaced Marlboro File:Schumacher Canada 2005 FP.jpg|A Ferrari F2005 being driven by Michael Schumacher at the 2005 Canada GP with the Marlboro "Barcode". File:Michael Schumacher 2006 USA.jpg|[[Michael Schumacher]] driving the [[Ferrari 248 F1]] at the [[2006 United States Grand Prix]], showing sponsorship from [[Vodafone]], [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell]], and the Marlboro "barcode". File:Felipe Massa 2006 Brazil winner.jpg|[[Felipe Massa]] winning the [[2006 Brazilian Grand Prix]] driving the [[Ferrari 248 F1]] with Marlboro replaced by bar codes and with added sponsors from [[Martini (vermouth)|Martini]] and [[Bridgestone]] File:Kimi Raikkonen won 2007 Brazil GP.jpg|[[Kimi Räikkönen]] driving the [[Ferrari F2007]] winning the [[2007 Brazilian Grand Prix]] and the World Drivers' Championship for the first time. The car itself at the start of the year had Marlboro sponsorship but dropped it by the European season File:Ferrari Raikkonen 2008 Spanish GP.jpg|[[Kimi Räikkönen]] driving the [[Ferrari F2008]] at the [[2008 Spanish Grand Prix]]. The car lacked any sponsorship and featured the flags of [[England]] and [[Scotland]] File:Hesketh 308D Donington.jpg|1976 Hesketh 308D. Image shows well the large painted Penthouse Pet, apparently initially painted topless, but the Rizla packet was added for decency. File:Hesketh 308E.jpg|1977 Penthouse Rizla Racing Hesketh 308E-Cosworth waiting in the pit garages during the Silverstone Classic race meeting </gallery> </center>
==Hill==
The [[Embassy Hill]], founded by two-time World Champion [[Graham Hill]], raced during the 1975 season with Imperial Tobacco's Embassy brand as title sponsor. The cars were predominantly white, with a red vertical stripe behind the cockpit. The team folded following the aircraft accident in which Hill, driver [[Tony Brise]] and four other team members were killed in November 1975.
==Honda== [[Honda Racing F1|Honda]] first raced in Formula One from [[1964 Formula One season|1964]] to [[1968 Formula One season|1968]]. The cars were entered in an all-white livery with a red circle, duplicating the [[Flag of Japan|Japanese flag]]. The company won several races but left F1 at the end of the 1968 season, before returning as an engine supplier in the 1980s. Honda in the 1990s never raced, but created prototypes like the RC 100 and the RA099 tested at Suzuka Circuit. After a decade away from the sport, Honda returned again as an engine supplier in [[2001 Formula One season|2001]], before buying the [[British American Racing]] team and entering F1 as a constructor in [[2006 Formula One season|2006]]. For the 2006 season, Honda continued with the [[British American Tobacco|BAT]] sponsorship with the Lucky Strike logo, but BAT pulled out for 2007. From 2007, the only logos on the car are the [[Honda]] badge, the [[Bridgestone]] logo, and the logo of Honda's environmental awareness program, Earth Dreams. For 2007, the livery itself was a picture of the Earth on a black background. For 2008, however, there are only pieces of the image of Earth on a mainly white background, as opposed to the whole of the Earth being on Honda's car.

==HRT== The [[HRT F1|HRT Formula 1 Team]] competed for just three seasons, between [[2010 Formula One season|2010]] and [[2012 Formula One season|2012]]. In that time, the team competed with three different liveries, this was due to a lack of sponsor continuity.

==LEC== LEC was a Formula One team and constructor from the United Kingdom. They participated in ten Grands Prix, using a March in 1973. In 1977 they built their own car, the LEC CRP1.

==Lotus (1958–1994)== At the [[1968 Spanish Grand Prix]] the [[Team Lotus|Lotus]] became the second team (after [[Team Gunston]] at the [[1968 South African Grand Prix]])<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wheels24.co.za/FormulaOne/sa-was-ahead-of-the-curve-50-years-of-sponsorship-in-f1-20180320|title='SA was ahead of the curve' - 50 years of sponsorship in F1|website=wheels24.co.za|accessdate=4 October 2018}}</ref> to abandon the national colour system when the possibility to do so was created in {{F1|1968}}. Lotus also had one of the longest sponsorship cooperations in Formula One history, making the black and gold of its 1972–1986 John Player Special seasons one of the best known liveries to this day.

File:Lotus_92_Donington.jpg|A Lotus 92 in display Image:Mansell_Lotus_95T_Dallas_1984_F1.jpg|Nigel Mansell driving his Lotus 95T at the 1984 Dallas Grand Prix File:Lotus_95T_Elio_De_Angelis_Detroit_Grand_Prix_1984a.jpeg|Lotus 95T in the garages of the 1984 Detroit Grand Prix Image:Senna Brands 1986.jpg|However, the partnership was soon renewed, although the JPS logo had to be replaced with a non-tobacco livery on [[Ayrton Senna]]'s [[Lotus 98T]] at the [[1986 British Grand Prix]]. File:Elio_de_Angelis_im_Lotus-Renault_1985-08-02.jpg|Elio de Angelis driving a Lotus97T at the 1985 German GP File:Lotus97T.jpg|1985 Ayrton Senna Lotus 97T at the Renault World Series File:Lotus_99T_front-right_2010_Pavilion_Pit_Stop.jpg|Ayrton Senna's Lotus 99T from 1987 Season File:Lotus 99T right Honda Collection Hall.jpg|Satoru Nakajima's Lotus 99T from 1987 Season File:Nelson_Piquet_1988_Canada.jpg|Nelson Piquet driving for Lotus at the 1988 Canada Grand Prix Image:Lotus 100T Honda Collection.jpg|Lotus were sponsored by [[Camel (cigarette)|Camel]] in the period {{F1|1987}}–{{F1|1990}}. File:Lotus_100T_front_view_Honda_Collection_Hall.jpg|A Lotus 100T on display at the Honda Collection Hall in Japan. File:Lotus102d.jpg|A Lotus 102D from 1992 in display File:Herbert_at_1993_British_Grand_Prix_(cropped).jpg|Johnny Herbert driving for Lotus at the 1993 British GP File:Johnny_Herbert_Lotus_1994.jpg|Johnny Herbert driving for Lotus at the 1994 British GP </gallery> </center>
==Lotus (2010–2011)== The [[Team Lotus (2010–11)|new Lotus team]] made its début in 2010 and was renamed to [[Caterham F1]] in 2012. It was formally from Malaysia but still had a livery dominated by [[British racing green]], like the [[Team Lotus|old Lotus team]] had for many years.

==Lotus (2012–2015)==
The [[Renault in Formula One|Renault team]] was renamed to [[Lotus F1 Team|Lotus]] in 2012, following an agreement with [[Caterham F1]]. The team is owned by Luxembourg-based venture capital group [[Genii Capital]] and named after its branding partner [[Group Lotus]]. Its livery, introduced back in 2011 with [[Renault R31]], was designed as a tribute to the [[Team Lotus]] cars of 1981–1986 and their famous [[John Player & Sons|John Player Special]] liveries.
{| class="wikitable" |- !Year !Main colour(s) !Additional colour(s) !Livery sponsor(s) !Additional major sponsor(s) !Notes |- |{{F1|2012}} |Black |Gold, Red |[[Lotus Cars|Lotus]], [[Genii Capital|Genii]] |[[Total S.A.|Total]], [[Rexona]], [[Unilever|CLEAR]], [[Trina Solar]], [[TW Steel]], [[Renault]], [[Microsoft Dynamics]], [[Avanade]], Japan Rags, [[Advanced Global Trading]], Auden Mckenzie Group, [[Pirelli]] |The team partnered with alternative rock band [[Linkin Park]] at the [[2012 Monaco Grand Prix]] to promote an [[iPad]] application.<br/>The team promoted the movie ''[[Dark Knight Rises]]'' at the [[2012 British Grand Prix]]. |- |{{F1|2013}} |Black, Red |Gold |[[Lotus Cars|Lotus]], [[Genii Capital|Genii]] |[[Total S.A.|Total]], [[Rexona]], [[Unilever|CLEAR]], [[Burn (energy drink)|Burn]], [[Renault]], [[Microsoft Dynamics]], [[Columbia Records]], Japan Rags, [[Advanced Global Trading]], [[CNBC]], [[Avanade]], Auden Mckenzie Group, [[Peace One Day]], [[Pirelli]] |The Lotus livery changed a little for 2013, with both cars featuring their drivers' respective names near the top air intake. Rumours said that the team was close to signing [[Honeywell]] as their sponsor and changed the livery accordingly in advance.<ref>''[http://www.motorsport.com/f1/news/lotus-yet-to-sign-honeywell-title-deal/ Lotus yet to sign Honeywell title deal]'' Motorsport.com, 25 January 2013. Retrieved 18 March 2013.</ref> |- |{{F1|2014}} |Black, Red |Gold |[[Lotus Cars|Lotus]], [[Genii Capital|Genii]], [[EMC Corporation|EMC]], [[PDVSA]] |[[Total S.A.|Total]], [[Saxo Bank]], [[Rexona]], [[Unilever|CLEAR]], [[Burn (energy drink)|Burn]], [[Renault]], [[Microsoft Dynamics]], [[Columbia Records]], [[Yota|Yota Devices]], [[Avanade]], [[Richard Mille]], [[Peace One Day]], Venezuela Tourism, [[Pirelli]] |- |{{F1|2015}} |Black |Gold, Red |[[Lotus Cars|Lotus]], [[Genii Capital|Genii]], [[EMC Corporation|EMC]], [[PDVSA]] |[[Pirelli]], [[Saxo Bank]], [[Microsoft Dynamics]], [[Mercedes-Benz]], [[Richard Mille]], [[Altran]], [[Yota|Yota Devices]], [[CD-adapco]], [[Peace One Day]], Elysium Inc., Venezuela Tourism, [[Microsoft Lumia]] |The team promoted the movie ''[[Mad Max: Fury Road]]'' at the [[2015 Spanish Grand Prix]]. |}

==McLaren== [[McLaren]] had one of the longest sponsorship deals in F1 history with [[Marlboro (cigarette)|Marlboro]], whose red-and-white pattern appeared on the team's cars for 23 straight years.<ref>''[http://www.grandprix.com/ft/ftdt022.html White and Red – All Over?]'' grandprix.com. Retrieved 8 February 2010.</ref>

==Mercedes-Benz==
[[Mercedes-Benz in Formula One|Mercedes-Benz]] first competed in [[Formula One]] during the {{f1|1954}} and {{f1|1955}} seasons. This was in the time before sponsorship liveries and the team was using an all silver livery, the national racing color of Germany. The team was absent from Formula One after this, returning in {{f1|1994}} as an engine supplier.
Mercedes-Benz rejoined [[Formula One]] as a team in {{f1|2010}} after having purchased the [[Brawn GP]] team on 16 November 2009. On 21 December 2009 it signed a €30 million per season contract with [[Petronas]] as ''title sponsor''.<ref>''[http://www.jamesallenonf1.com/2009/12/mercedes-lands-e30-million-petronas-sponsorship/ Mercedes lands €30 million Petronas sponsorship.]'' jamesallenonf1.com. Retrieved 29 January 2010.</ref> On 25 January 2010 Mercedes GP unveiled the car livery for the 2010 season.<ref>''[http://f1.gpupdate.net/en/formula-1-news/226604/mercedes-reveals-2010-livery/ Mercedes reveals 2010 livery.]{{cbignore}}{{dead link|date=February 2015}}'' f1.gpupdate.net/en/. Retrieved 27 January 2010.</ref> The blueish green livery color of Petronas is just present as fine lines at the side of the car, which overall is mainly painted in silver like the old time Mercedes race cars of the 1930s and 1950s.

==Midland== [[Midland F1]] competed for only one year, 2006. They took over [[Jordan Grand Prix|Jordan]] in 2005, but Midland sold it in late 2006 to [[Spyker F1|Spyker]]. They were the first F1 team to compete with a Russian license. (After Spyker's takeover in mid-2006, the team changed its livery to orange and name to Spyker MF1 Racing. In 2007, the team competed as Spyker F1.)

==Rebaque== Rebaque is the only Mexican team in F1 to date. Named after its driver Héctor Rebaque, it always raced with a brown and gold livery.

==Red Bull Racing==
[[Jaguar Racing]] was renamed [[Red Bull Racing]] after the former was bought from Ford on 15 November 2004 by the energy drink company.<ref name="Jaguarsold">{{cite news|title= Red Bull snaps up Jaguar F1 team|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/4012381.stm|work =| publisher = BBC Sport| date =15 November 2004| accessdate = 28 January 2007}}</ref> [[Red Bull]]'s involvement in Formula One dates back to {{f1|1995}}, when it first sponsored the [[Sauber]] team. The deal with Sauber lasted until the end of the {{f1|2004}} season.
Since its first season in {{f1|2005}} the car livery did not change much, always keeping Red Bull as the main sponsor. This changed in [[2013 Formula One season|2013]], when [[Infiniti]] became the team's title sponsor and Red Bull's branding on the car was reduced.
Red Bull have used special liveries on multiple occasions, supporting the release up upcoming films and company's charity program Wings for Life.

==Renault== [[Renault in Formula One|Renault]] entered Formula One in [[1977 Formula One season|1977]] and withdrew as a team after the [[1985 Formula One season|1985 season]]. Renault returned to Formula One in [[2002 Formula One season|2002]] by buying the [[Benetton Formula|Benetton team]]. Renault had a contract with [[Mild Seven]] from 2002 to 2006, and had a title contract with [[ING Group]] from 2007 to Italian Grand Prix 2009 when ING withdrew all association with Renault. The team was later sold and became [[Lotus F1|Lotus]] in 2012, before Renault bought back the team and returned as a constructor in {{F1|2016}}.

==Sauber==
[[Sauber]] is a Swiss Formula One constructor that joined the Formula One grid in [[1993 Formula One season|1993]]. At the end of the [[2005 Formula One season|2005 season]] it was bought by [[BMW]] and from [[2006 Formula One season|2006]] to [[2009 Formula One season|2009]] it raced as [[BMW in Formula One|BMW Sauber F1 Team]]. On 27 November 2009, BMW agreed to sell the team back to its original founder, [[Peter Sauber]].<ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/> The [[2010 Formula One season]] marked Sauber's return as an independent constructor.

==Spyker== Spyker took part in only one season of Formula One. The main colour of the car did not directly reflect the sponsorships but was the orange racing colour of the Netherlands.

==Stewart== [[Stewart Grand Prix|Stewart]] lasted for only 3 years before being bought out by its engine supplier, [[Ford]], and being rebranded as [[Jaguar Cars|Jaguar]], but managed to win a race in its final season, [[1999 Formula One Season|1999]]. Stewart had a tartan decoration on its cars to represent its Scottish nationality.

==Super Aguri== [[Super Aguri]] was set up before the 2006 season by [[Aguri Suzuki]], with the help of [[Honda Racing F1 Team|Honda Racing]], to provide a drive for former Honda driver [[Takuma Sato]]. For the 2006 season's SA05 and SA06, their car was based on the 2002 Arrows A23, after which, for the 2007 and 2008 seasons, they ran cars based on the previous year's Honda chassis.

==Toro Rosso== [[Toro Rosso]] is the sister team of [[Red Bull Racing]]. Since it originated from the buyout of [[Minardi]], its name means Red Bull in Italian.<ref>''[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/motorsport/formula_one/4227936.stm Red Bull swoop for Minardi deal.]'' bbc.co.uk. Retrieved 3 February 2010.</ref> At the beginning, the team used to have the same name and sponsors as its parent team, with the major difference being the presence of a scarlet "charging bull" painted over the engine cowling.

==Toyota== When car manufacturers started to concentrate in their own F1 teams at the start of the decade, [[Toyota Racing|Toyota]] was one of them. As main rival Honda did, they always painted their cars with the same white/red color scheme, instead of any sponsor colors.

==Tyrrell== [[Tyrrell Racing]] competed in Formula One from {{F1|1970}}–{{F1|1998}}. Its traditional colour was blue and white, or a combination as such, for most of the 1970s and 1980s. The cars were more white during the mid to late 1990s.

==Virgin==
The [[Virgin Group]]'s involvement with [[Formula One]] started in {{f1|2009}} when they decided to sponsor [[Brawn GP]] for that season.<ref>''[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/motorsport/formula_one/7969435.stm Virgin to sponsor Brawn F1 team.]''bbc.co.uk. Retrieved 4 February 2010.</ref> On 30 November 2009 it was reported that the Manor GP, one of the four newcomers teams for the {{f1|2010}} season, would be rebranded as [[Virgin Racing]].<ref>''[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/motorsport/formula_one/8387634.stm Manor GP set to be rebranded as Virgin Racing.]'' bbc.co.uk. Retrieved 4 February 2010.</ref>

==Williams== [[Williams Grand Prix Engineering|Williams]], as a major constructor, is rare in modern F1 in that they have no manufacturer backing. Over the years, their supply of engines and other major components has often changed, meaning that their livery is renewed more often than most of their rivals. Sponsors of Williams can often have the livery dramatically changed, which has helped to keep Williams competitively financed since [[1978 Formula One season|1978]], when Williams first entered as a constructor.<ref>''[http://williams.latphoto.co.uk/?page=Images&cat=1 Photography archive.]''williamsf1.com. Retrieved 3 February 2010.</ref> The BMW-engined Williams cars from 2001-2006 featured a dark blue and white scheme with stylized BMW "kidney grille", which resembled Brabham's BMW-engined cars from the 1980s.

revision.text: #REDIRECT [[General manager#Sports teams]] [[Category:Sports executives and administrators|*]]

The '''Gundersen method''' is a method in the [[Nordic combined]] developed by [[Gunder Gundersen]], a Nordic combined athlete from [[Norway]], that was first used in the 1980s. This technique turned the [[cross country skiing]] part of the Nordic combined from a point-based system where all athletes ski in an [[Time trial|interval start]] manner and whoever earned the most points with the [[ski jumping]] part of the Nordic combined won the event to a [[pursuit racing|pursuit]] race for the cross country skiing part where whoever crossed the finish line first in the cross country skiing part of the Nordic combined event won the competition. This parallels the [[modern pentathlon]] in which the start times of the final event (a cross-country run) are also staggered so that the first to cross the finish line is the winner of the entire event.
Initially put in at the [[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 1985]] and at the [[1988 Winter Olympics]], the event point-time differential has been adjusted at every [[Winter Olympics]]. The table below is one point difference at the ski jump equaliing a specific number of seconds between skiers or teams at the start of the cross country portion of the event.
{| class="wikitable" ![[Winter Olympics|Winter Olympic Games]] !Individual (includes 7.5 km sprint) !Team |- |align="center"|[[Nordic combined at the 1988 Winter Olympics|1988]] |align="center"|6.7<ref name=w1>Wallechinsky, David and Jaime Loucky (2009). "Nordic Combined: Individual". In ''The Complete Book of the Winter Olympics: 2010 Edition''. London: Aurum Press. p. 274-6.</ref> |align="center"|5<ref name=w2>Wallechinsky, David and Jaime Loucky (2009). "Nordic Combined: Team". In ''The Complete Book of the Winter Olympics: 2010 Edition''. London: Aurum Press. p. 277-80.</ref> |- |align="center"|[[Nordic combined at the 1992 Winter Olympics|1992]] |align="center"|6.7<ref name=w1 /> |align="center"|5<ref name=w2 /> |- |align="center"|[[Nordic combined at the 1994 Winter Olympics|1994]] |align="center"|6.5<ref name=w1 /> |align="center"|5<ref name=w2 /> |- |align="center"|[[Nordic combined at the 1998 Winter Olympics|1998]] |align="center"|6<ref name=w1 /> |align="center"|3<ref name=w2 /> |- |align="center"|[[Nordic combined at the 2002 Winter Olympics|2002]] |align="center"|5<ref name=w1 /> |align="center"|1.5<ref name=w2 /> |- |align="center"|[[Nordic combined at the 2006 Winter Olympics|2006]] |align="center"|4<ref name=w1 /> |align="center"|1<ref name=w2 /> |- |align="center"|[[Nordic combined at the 2010 Winter Olympics|2010]] |align="center"|4<ref name=icr>[http://www.fis-ski.com/data/document/icr_nc_2008.pdf FIS International Competition Rules for Nordic Combined 2008.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019054554/http://www.fis-ski.com/data/document/icr_nc_2008.pdf |date=2012-10-19 }} p. 76 (shown in Acrobat file as p. 78.) - accessed 21 December 2009.</ref> |align="center"|1.33<ref name=icr /> |}

[[Augusta GreenJackets]] ([[South Atlantic League|SAL]]) 1994 | embedded = | website = | publictransit = }} '''Heaton Stadium''' was a [[baseball stadium]] in [[Augusta, Georgia]], United States. It was the home field of the [[Augusta Pirates]]/[[Augusta GreenJackets]] [[Minor League Baseball]] team of the [[Class A (baseball)|Class A]] [[South Atlantic League]] from 1988 to 1994. After the 1994 season the site was redeveloped as the GreenJackets' next home, [[Lake Olmstead Stadium]]. Heaton Stadium was named for Bill Heaton, a retired Army lieutenant colonel and partner in the team ownership who worked for six years to bring a minor league club to Augusta.{{cite news |title=Macon Baseball Franchise to Move to Augusta |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1987-10-11/sports/sp-13568_1_minor-league-baseball |accessdate=November 11, 2018 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=October 11, 1987}} Heaton reportedly built the stadium with his own money,{{cite book |last1=Mullins |first1=Robert A. |title=12 Monkeys & a Green Jacket |date=May 2014 |publisher=[[Xlibris Corporation]] |isbn=9781493189717 |page=197 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xiyeAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA197&lpg=PA197&dq=Bill-Heaton+augusta&source=bl&ots=CDzBFHiOn6&sig=3Qf-BwFk-XWdHL2Lqdrr0gWuDxc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiitN6hq9ncAhWTHjQIHZ5WB0UQ6AEwEnoECFYQAQ#v=onepage&q=Bill-Heaton%20augusta&f=false |accessdate=November 11, 2018}} assembling bleachers bought from other locations{{cite news |last1=Kirby |first1=Bill |title=WAY WE WERE: Bill Heaton builds a ballfield, lures a team |url=http://chronicle.augusta.com/news/2017-09-03/way-we-were-bill--ballfield-lures-team |accessdate=November 11, 2018 |work=[[The Augusta Chronicle]] |date=September 3, 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170904035853/http://chronicle.augusta.com/news/2017-09-03/way-we-were-bill-heaton-builds-ballfield-lures-team |archivedate=September 4, 2017}} with the help of volunteers and high school workers paid minimum wage.{{cite news |last1=Boyette |first1=John |title=Bill Heaton, who brought minor league baseball back to Augusta, dies |url=http://chronicle.augusta.com/news/sports/2017-08-08/bill-heaton-who-brought-minor-league-baseball-back-augusta-dies |accessdate=November 11, 2018 |work=[[The Augusta Chronicle]] |date=August 8, revision.comment: /* References */add category
revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=December 2010}} '''Howard Head''' (July 31, 1914 in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]] – March 3, 1991) was an [[aeronautical engineer]] who is credited with the invention of the first commercially successful aluminum [[laminate]] [[skis]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Skiing History journal: A short history of skis|url=https://skiinghistory.org/history/short-history-skis-0|accessdate=19 December 2016}}</ref> and the oversized [[tennis racket]]. Head founded the ski (and later tennis racquet) making firm [[Head (company)|Head]] in 1950. Later he became chairman of [[Prince Sports|Prince]] Manufacturing Inc. The U.S. [[patents]] for the laminate skis and oversized tennis racket are in the name of Howard Head.<ref>{{cite web|title=The History of Howard Head|url=http://www.chrisoleary.com/projects/TheParadoxOfPain/Documents/TheParadoxOfPain_TheStoryOfHowardHead.pdf|accessdate=24 June 2012}}</ref>
==Ski equipment == [[File:Ski.jpg|thumb|right|90px|A Head Ski Company alpine ski, 2006 model.]] In 1947, Howard Head was an aircraft engineer for [[Glenn L. Martin Company]] in [[Baltimore, Maryland|Baltimore]], and went [[Alpine skiing|skiing]] for the first time. Head was frustrated with the quality of the clumsy and heavy wooden skis, which made skiing very difficult for beginners. He decided to develop a lighter and more efficient ski that could make skiing much easier for everyone. He left his job and devoted all his time and energy to developing the skis and supported himself with earnings from [[poker]].
The skis developed by Head were based on the structural principles that he had learned during his experience as an aircraft engineer. In a warehouse he rented from Albert Gunther Inc in an alley off of Biddle Street in downtown Baltimore, he used a technique known as metal sandwich construction. The first skis he made consisted of two light layers of [[aluminum]] bonded to sidewalls of thin [[plywood]], with a center filling of honeycomb plastic. Although these skis were very light, they all broke quite quickly during trials. Head did not give up on his idea, and was encouraged by several professional skiers, including 1939 World Champion [[Emile Allais]] and ski instructors Clif Taylor and Neil Robinson, who assured Head that he would love to use his skis if they did not break. Throughout that winter Head would make a ski pair and send it out to Robinson, who returned it to Head after it broke. Head figured out the flaws of his design, came up with modifications, sent the new ski pair to Robinson, and the process repeated. By the end of the winter of 1947, Head came up with skis that were as strong as wooden skis but were half the weight.
In order to make his skis more efficient, Head made several other changes, like substituting plywood for honeycomb plastic, covering the bottom of the ski with polyethylene to avoid the problem of icy bottoms and adopting continuous steel edges to harden the edges of the ski. The new improved skis were almost as heavy as the conventional wooden skis, but were stronger and easier to control. Head skis helped to popularize alpine skiing in the U.S.; the innovative equipment made turning significantly easier.
In 1950, Head founded the Head Ski Company, which became very successful. Within a couple of years it was the major supplier of alpine skis in the [[United States of America|U.S.]] and influenced ski design worldwide. The company later diversified into [[tennis]] and other racquet sports; its most notable product was the innovative [[Arthur Ashe]] racquet, constructed of aluminum honeycomb. Howard Head sold the company to [[American Machine and Foundry|AMF]] in 1969 and retired. After a number of takeovers and acquisitions, [[Head (company)|HEAD, N.V.]] is currently based in [[Kennelbach]], Austria (operational) and [[Amsterdam]], [[Netherlands]] (corporate offices).
== Tennis racquet == After retiring, Head decided to take tennis lessons and for this purpose he got himself a tennis ball machine, which was manufactured by [[Prince Sports|Prince Manufacturing Inc.]] Although Howard was not very good at tennis, he figured out that the equipment for the game needed a lot of improvement or he was going to need a lot more practice. To begin with he became the majority shareholder and chairman of the board of Prince. While Head considerably improved the design of the ball machine, he still did not get any better at the game. He figured it out that it was because of the small sweet-spot of the tennis racquet. In order to make the game of tennis easier, Head came up with the design of oversized racquet. He filed and obtained a patent that covered tennis racquets with size 95–135 square inches. He also pioneered the development of the [[graphite]] racquet, which eventually became the industry standard, replacing wooden racquets.
Although Prince was the first company to patent oversize racquets, the [[Bentley Fortissimo]] preceded the patent by two years, causing Germany to invalidate it. [[Tad Weed|Weed]] also introduced an oversize racquet in 1975, before the first Prince oversize, the aluminum Prince Classic, was introduced.
==External links== * [http://www.nevasport.com/nevablogs/detalle.php?id_blogs=31&id_articulos=847 Howard Head] * [http://www.tennisserver.com/set/set_03_06.html An interview with Howard Broody.] – the physics behind Head's Racquet * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050828211241/http://www.inventionatplay.org/inventors_hea.html Invention at play.org] – inventors – Howard Head * [http://www.head.com/corporate/history.php Head.com] – timeline * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050807003939/http://www.princetennis.com/companyinfo/history.asp Prince Tennis.com] – history
{{Authority control}}

page.title: List of Women's Basketball Academic All-America Team Members of the Year

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2016}} {{main|List of Academic All-America Team Members of the Year}} {{Infobox award | name = Women's Basketball Academic All-America Team Members of the Year | image = | imagesize = | caption = | description = The yearly outstanding women's [[college basketball]] [[Academic All-America]] team member | presenter = [[Capital One]] & the [[College Sports Information Directors of America]] | country = [[United States]] & [[Canada]] | location = | year = | holder = Cherise Beynon, [[New Mexico Lobos women's basketball|New Mexico]]
Miranda Ristau, [[Northern State Wolves|Northern State]]
Samm Chandler, [[Averett University|Averett]]
Amber Alexander, [[Vanguard University|Vanguard]] | website = [http://academicallamerica.com academicallamerica.com] }} '''List of Women's Basketball Academic All-America Team Members of the Year''' is a list of the annual selection by the [[College Sports Information Directors of America]] and its [[Academic All-America]] sponsor of the individual athlete selected as the most outstanding of the annual Women's Basketball Academic All-America selections. From 1996 through 2011, one winner each was chosen from both the College and University Divisions for all twelve Academic All-America teams, including football. The Academic All-America program recognizes combined athletic and academic excellence of the nation's top student-athletes. The University Division team included eligible participants from [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] (NCAA) [[NCAA Division I|Division I]] member schools, while the College Division team included scholar-athletes from all of the following: [[NCAA Division II]], [[NCAA Division III]], [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics]] (NAIA), [[List of universities in Canada|Canadian universities]] and [[List of colleges in Canada|colleges]] and two-year schools. Beginning in 2012, COSIDA revamped its award structure. The University Division was renamed "Division I". NCAA Divisions II and III now have their own separate All-Americans, while the College Division now consists only of non-NCAA institutions. Currently, each team selects Academic All-District honorees in eight geographic districts across the United States and Canada.{{cite web|url=http://cosida.com/media/documents/2011/2/2010_11_AAA_MBB_All_District_Teams.pdf|title=Capital One Academic All-District ® Men’s Basketball Teams Released|accessdate=March 22, 2011|date=February 3, 2011|publisher=[[College Sports Information Directors of America]]}} First team All-District honorees make the All-America team ballots. Currently, all twelve Academic All-American teams (Men's and women's [[basketball]], men's and women's [[soccer]], men's and women's [[track & field]], men's [[baseball]], women's [[softball]], men's [[American football]], women's [[volleyball]] and men's and women's at-large teams) have one Academic All-American of the Year for each division. One of these twelve sport-by-sport Academic All-American of the year is selected as the [[List of Academic All-America Team Members of the Year|Academic All-America Team Members of the Year]] for each division.{{cite web|url=http://cosida.com/media/documents/2011/1/Academic_AllAmerica_FAQs.pdf|title=Academic All-America program Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)|accessdate=March 22, 2011|publisher=[[College Sports Information Directors of America]]}} The most recent women's basketball player to have earned the all-sports honor is Lauren Battista of [[Bentley University]] in Massachusetts, winner of the 2014 Division II award.{{cite press release|url=http://www.cosida.com/news/2014/7/29/AAA_0729142202.aspx |title=Bentley's Battista named Capital One D2 Academic All-America® of the Year |publisher=College Sports Information Directors of America |date=July 31, 2014 |accessdate=August 3, 2014}} ==University Division/Division I== All winners are Americans unless indicated otherwise. Names in '''bold''' were winners of the all-sports Academic All-America Award. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin:1em 0; font-size:90%;" |- style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0f0;" revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox NFL single game | name = Miracle in Motown | image = [[File:Ford-Field-September-10-2006.jpg|250px]] | caption = Ford Field in Detroit, site of the game. | visitor = [[2015 Green Bay Packers season|Green Bay Packers]] | visitor_abbr = GB | visitor_coach = [[Mike McCarthy (American football)|Mike McCarthy]] | visitor_record = 8–4 | home = [[2015 Detroit Lions season|Detroit Lions]] | home_abbr = DET | home_coach = [[Jim Caldwell (American football)|Jim Caldwell]] | home_record = 4–8 | visitor_qtr1 = 0 | visitor_qtr2 = 0 | visitor_qtr3 = 14 | visitor_qtr4 = 13 | visitor_total = 27 | home_qtr1 = 17 | home_qtr2 = 0 | home_qtr3 = 3 | home_qtr4 = 3 | home_total = 23 | date = December 3, 2015 | stadium = [[Ford Field]] | city = [[Detroit|Detroit, Michigan]] | network = [[CBS]], [[NFL Network]] | announcers = [[Jim Nantz]], [[Phil Simms]], [[Tracy Wolfson]] | referee = [[Carl Cheffers]] }} The '''Miracle in Motown''' was the final play of an [[American football]] game between the [[NFC North]] divisional rivals [[Green Bay Packers]] and [[Detroit Lions]] on December 3, 2015. The game, which was broadcast on television nationally on ''[[Thursday Night Football]]'', was played at [[Ford Field]] in [[Detroit, Michigan]] during the [[2015 NFL season]]. On the final play of regulation, with no time remaining on the game clock, Packers [[quarterback]] (QB) [[Aaron Rodgers]] threw a {{convert|61|yd|m|adj=on}} [[Hail Mary pass]] into the end-zone that was caught by [[tight end]] (TE) [[Richard Rodgers (American football)|Richard Rodgers]] for the game-winning [[touchdown]]. The play resulted in a dramatic 27–23 come-from-behind victory for the Packers, who had trailed 20–0 in the second half. The victory was the Packers fourth-largest comeback in franchise history. It was also the start of a 3–game winning streak that would help the Packers clinch their seventh consecutive postseason berth. The Lions would end the season with a record of 7–9 and fail to reach the playoffs. ==Background== Before the game on December 3, 2015, the Green Bay Packers had struggled in their previous games, while the Detroit Lions had found their form since winning against the Packers on the road at [[Lambeau Field]] in [[Green Bay, Wisconsin|Green Bay]]. The Packers had lost four of their last five games after a 6–0 start for the season and were in dire need of a change of fortune to reach the playoffs. Meanwhile, the Detroit Lions came to the game with a three-game winning streak, and they still had a chance to earn a playoff spot despite starting the season with a 1-7 record. Eighteen days earlier, the Lions had ended a 24-year winless streak against the Packers in a road game by beating them 18–16 at [[Lambeau Field]]. If they had also defeated the Packers at their second meeting of the season, the Lions would have swept the season series with Green Bay for the first time since 1991.{{cite news |url= http://espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=400791568 |title= Packers Stun Lions on Aaron Rodgers-to-Richard Rodgers Hail Mary |publisher= [[ESPN]] |date= December 4, 2015 |access-date= December 6, 2015}} Before the Packers started their comeback from the 20–0 deficit in the second half of the game, the Lions had snapped a 56-game streak during which the Packers had scored in the first half. Counting the previous game against the [[Chicago Bears]] and the greater part of the Lions game, Packers went nearly 70 game-minutes without scoring a point. ==Events of the play== With six seconds left on the game clock, Green Bay was on 3rd-and-10 at its own 21-yard line. After one forward pass and one backward pass, Packers tight end Richard Rodgers lateraled the ball to quarterback Aaron Rodgers, who was quickly tackled at his 24-yard line by Detroit Lions defender [[Devin Taylor]], with the game clock having gone to zero during the play. However, the official standing behind the play called a 15-yard penalty on Taylor for a face mask foul on the tackle, and so, because NFL rules state that a game cannot end on a defensive penalty, the Packers were given an [[untimed play]] at their own 39-yard line.{{cite news |first= Eric |last= Edholm |url= https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/nfl-shutdown-corner/miracle-in-motown--packers-stun-lions-on-controversial-walk-off-td-050026407.html |title= Miracle in Motown: Packers Stun Lions on Controversial Walk-off Touchdown |work=[[Yahoo! Sports]] |publisher= Yahoo! |date= December 4, 2015 |access-date= December 4, 2015}}{{cite news|last=Slusher|first=Keenan|title=Miracle in Motown: Rodgers Connects with Rodgers on Hail Mary|url=http://nfl.nbcsports.com/2015/12/04/miracle-in-motown-rodgers-connects-with-rodgers-on-hail-mary|publisher=[[NBC Sports]]|date=December 4, 2015|accessdate=December 4, 2015}}{{cite news|last=Wagner-McGough|first=Sean|title=Look: Twitter Can't Believe the Miracle in Motown Actually Happened|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/eye-on-football/25400426/look-twitter-cant-believe-the-miracle-in-motown-actually-happened|publisher=[[CBS Sports]]|date=December 4, 2015|accessdate=December 4, 2015}} After the snap, all Packers receivers ran towards the end zone and Aaron Rodgers broke right, escaping the Detroit defenders before throwing a {{convert|61|yd|m|adj=on}} Hail Mary pass into the end zone.{{cite news |first1= Jim |last1= Nantz |first2= Phil |last2= Simms |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r0vVqStvh_8|title=Aaron Rodgers' Amazing Hail Mary: The Miracle in Motown! Packers vs. Lions |work= Thursday Night Football |publisher= CBS Sports |via= [[National Football League]] on [[YouTube]] |date= December 3, 2015 |access-date= December 4, 2015}} Tight end Richard Rodgers, who was the last player to reach the end zone, leapt high in front of all defenders, caught the ball at full extension, and came down nearly unchallenged for the catch, resulting in the Packers winning 27–23 (the Packers chose to omit the extra-point attempt). According to a number of estimations, Aaron Rodgers' pass traveled {{convert|66|-|68|yd|m}} before reaching the hands of Richard Rodgers. The throw was also high enough to nearly hit the rafters at Ford Field.{{cite news |first= John |last= Breech |url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/eye-on-football/25401029/look-this-is-how-close-rodgers-hail-mary-came-to-hitting-the-rafters |title= Look: This Is How Close Rodger's Hail Mary Came to Hitting the Rafters |publisher= CBS Sports |date= December 4, 2015 |access-date= December 6, 2015}} The comeback victory was the fourth-largest in franchise history.{{cite news|url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/gnb/comebacks.htm|title=Green Bay Packers Greatest Comebacks|work=[[Pro-Football-Reference.com]]|date=December 4, 2015|accessdate=December 4, 2015}} {{quote|When you throw it with that arch you have a chance, because it gives guys a chance to fight for position. That’s the whole design of it, and there’s a design to where you try to get to and the triangle that you’re trying to form (with teammates) down there. Richard is the perfect guy for that type of situation, big body and his ability to go up—you see his old basketball skills—and high-point the football.|[[Mike McCarthy (American football)|Mike McCarthy]], the Packers head coach, breaking down the play{{cite news |url= http://www.greenbaypressgazette.com/story/sports/nfl/packers/insidersblog/2015/12/04/time-packers-winning-end-hail-mary/76768206/ |work= [[Green Bay Press-Gazette]] |first= Pete |last= Dougherty |title= This Time, Packers on Winning End of Hail Mary |date= December 4, 2015 |access-date= December 6, 2015}}"}} == Players involved == QB Aaron Rodgers and TE Richard Rodgers are not related, but both attended [[University of California, Berkeley]] and played for the [[California Golden Bears football|California Golden Bears]], graduating in 2005 and 2014, respectively. The play was Aaron Rodgers' first ever completed Hail Mary pass of his career, just one day after his 32nd birthday.{{cite news |first= Jason |last= Wilde |url= http://espn.go.com/blog/green-bay-packers/post/_/id/25587/throw-that-beat-lions-was-aaron-rodgers-first-ever-successful-hail-mary |title= Aaron Rodgers First Ever Hail Mary |publisher= ESPN |date= December 4, 2015 |access-date= December 6, 2015}} The Packers TE Richard Rodgers is the son of Richard Rodgers Sr., who was involved in one of the most famous plays in American football, "[[The Play (Stanford vs. California)|The Play]]", that ended the game between Cal and Stanford in 1982.{{cite news |first= Joe |last= DeLessio |url= http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2015/12/5-incredible-things-about-the-packers-hail-mary.html |title= 5 Incredible Things about the Packers' Hail Mary |work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |date= December 4, 2015 |access-date= December 4, 2015}} Richard Rodgers Sr. contended after the game that his son's role in the play rivaled his involvement in the famous play which he called and in which he threw two of the five laterals in 1982: {{quote|It's the complete scenario. If you look at it from my perspective, Rodgers throws it to Rodgers, not Aaron to Richard but Richard to Aaron, to start the whole thing. The penalty gets called. And then Rodgers throws it back to Rodgers again. I couldn't write a better script than that.|Richard Rodgers, Sr., father of TE [[Richard Rodgers (American football)|Richard Rodgers]]{{cite news |url= http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/eye-on-football/25400985/miracle-in-motown-has-an-incredible-link-to-the-stanford-cal-lateral-play |publisher= CBS Sports |first= Will |last= Brinson |title= Miracle in Motown Has an Incredible Link to the Stanford Cal Lateral Play |date= December 4, 2015 |access-date= December 6, 2015}}}} ==Penalty controversy== Like most significant calls by officials, the [[Face mask (gridiron football)|face mask penalty]] against Detroit that led to the winning play by Green Bay generated controversy.{{cite web|first=Sean|last=Wagner-McGough|title=LOOK: Twitter can't believe the Miracle in Motown actually happened|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/look-twitter-cant-believe-the-miracle-in-motown-actually-happened/|publisher=CBS Sports|date=December 4, 2015|accessdate=November 1, 2016}} Dean Blandino, NFL Vice President of Officiating, responded to the call on [[Twitter]] moments after the game: {{quote|Hand up to the mask, quick grab with finger and the head gets turned. At full speed, official is going to make that call almost every time.|NFL Vice President of Officiating, Dean Blandino, posted 12:05 a.m., December 4, 2015{{cite news |url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/eye-on-football/25400385/nfl-ref-czar-defends-controversial-facemask-penalty-in-miracle-in-motown |publisher= CBS Sports |first= Sean |last= Wagner-McGough |title= NFL Ref Czar Defends Controversial Face Mask Call in Miracle in Motown |date= December 4, 2015 |access-date= December 8, 2015}}}} During a visit by NFL officials to a Lions training camp in 2016, Carl Cheffers, the official who threw the flag, was asked about the penalty; he said "I think it was an illegal tackle. Horse-collar, facemask, I think it was an illegal tackle. I’m very comfortable with it."{{cite web|first=Justin|last=Rogers|title=Ref who flagged Lions before Hail Mary: It was right call|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/story/sports/nfl/lions/2016/08/05/ref-who-flagged-lions-before-hail-mary-right-call/88303842/|website=[[The Detroit News]]|date=August 5, 2016|accessdate=November 1, 2016}} ==Naming the play== The nickname for the play, "Miracle in Motown", was first used by Jim Nantz during the nationally broadcast ''[[Thursday Night Football]]'' postgame show.{{cite news|last=Verderame|first=Matt|title=Jim Nantz Coins Game 'Miracle in Motown'|url=http://fansided.com/2015/12/04/jim-nantz-coins-game-miracle-in-motown|work=Fansided|date=December 4, 2015|accessdate=December 4, 2015}} ==Broadcast calls of the final play== ===TV=== {{quote|'''Nantz:''' Rodgers, in trouble...
'''Simms:''' It's gonna get there.
'''Nantz:''' He turned 32 yesterday, does he have a vintage moment in him? In the end zone... IT IS CAUGHT! FOR THE WIN!!! Richard Rodgers with a walk-off touchdown! A game-ender for the Packers!|[[Thursday Night Football|TNF's]] [[Jim Nantz]] and [[Phil Simms]] calling the Hail Mary}} ===Radio=== {{quote|'''Larrivee:''' Snap to Rodgers, scrambles to his left, under pressure rolling right, escapes, right side looking, rainbows high and deep into the end zone...and it is CAUGHT! CAUGHT FOR A TOUCHDOWN!!! A leaping touchdown catch is made and the Packers have won!
'''McCarren:''' Unbelievable.
'''Larrivee:''' The Packers have won...on an extra play!|[[Wayne Larrivee]] and [[Larry McCarren]] from the [[Packers Radio Network]]}} {{quote|'''Miller:''' Rodgers rolling to his left, being chase, slips the tackle, Rodgers is stepping up lofting it deep down the field, into the end zone, it is up, and it is....CAUGHT!! CAUGHT BY THE PACKERS!!! RICHARD RODGERS FOR THE TOUCHDOWN! OH NO!!! Unbelievable! Rodgers on the final play of the game, slipped inside of all the defenders in the endzone, and made the catch for the score. Sixty-one yards, and the Lions have lost.|[[Dan Miller (sportscaster)|Dan Miller]] from [[Detroit Lions Radio Network]]}} ==Records== * Aaron Rodgers's pass is the longest game-winning Hail Mary play in NFL history. * The touchdown-throw distance of {{convert|61|yd|m|adj=pre|air}} from the line of scrimmage is the most air-yards on a touchdown in the previous 10 NFL seasons, and it was the second-longest offensive game-winning touchdown on the final play of regulation in NFL history. It came {{convert|4|yd|m|spell=in}} short of [[Earl Morrall]] and [[Jim Gibbons (American football)|Jim Gibbons]] combining for a {{convert|65|yd|m|adj=on}} game-winning play for the [[Detroit Lions]] in a 20–15 win over the [[Johnny Unitas]]-led [[Baltimore Colts]] in 1960.{{cite news |first= Jim |last= Reineking |url= http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000597494/article/packers-duo-from-cal-now-has-its-own-the-play |title= Packers' Duo from Cal Now Has Its Own 'The Play' |publisher= National Football League |date= December 8, 2015 |access-date= December 9, 2015}} * Overcoming a 20-point deficit represented the fourth-biggest comeback win in Packers franchise history. It rates behind a 23-point deficit in a 35–23 win over the [[Los Angeles Rams]] in 1982, a 23-point deficit in a 37–36 win over the [[Dallas Cowboys]] in 2013 (with [[Matt Flynn]] as a QB) and a 21-point deficit in a 35–34 win over the New Orleans Saints in 1989. This 20-point deficit was later tied in [[2018 Green Bay Packers season|2018]] when the Packers overcame a 20-point third quarter deficit to beat the [[Chicago Bears]] 24-23. * Before the final game-winning play, the Green Bay Packers had gone the full 60 minutes of the game without leading. * The play was named the "[[NFL Play of the Year Award|Bridgestone Performance Play of the Year]]" at the [[5th Annual NFL Honors]] ceremony the night before Super Bowl 50.{{cite news |first= Weston |last= Hodkiewicz |date= February 6, 2016 |url= http://www.sheboyganpress.com/story/sports/nfl/packers/insidersblog/2016/02/06/miracle-motown-wins-nfl-play-year/79950792/ |title= 'Miracle in Motown' Wins NFL Play of the Year |work= [[The Sheboygan Press]] |access-date= February 7, 2016}} * The play won the award for Best Play at the [[2016 ESPY Awards]].{{cite news |url = http://www.espn.com/espys/2016/story/_/id/17061236/2016-espy-awards |title = LeBron James, Cleveland Cavaliers Clean Up at ESPYs |author = ESPN.com |date = July 14, 2016 |publisher = ESPN |access-date = October 23, 2016}} ==See also== * [[2015 Green Bay Packers season]] * [[Lions–Packers rivalry]] * [[List of Hail Mary passes in American football]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{Youtube|id=r0vVqStvh_8|Highlight of the Miracle in Motown}} {{Green Bay Packers}} {{Detroit Lions}} {{NFL on CBS}} {{Thursday Night Football}} {{National Football League on television and radio}} [[Category:American football incidents]] [[Category:2015 in sports in Michigan]] [[Category:2015 National Football League season]] [[Category:Green Bay Packers]] [[Category:Detroit Lions]] [[Category:National Football League games]]

The event is affiliated with the [[Women's Tennis Association]] (WTA), and is part of the [[WTA International Tournaments|International tournaments]] on the [[WTA Tour]]. From 2009 to 2013 the tournament was held in the Sierra Madre Tennis Club, from 2014 the tournament is currently held at the Club Sonoma. ==Champions== ===Singles=== {|class=wikitable {{Infobox tennis tournament | name = Orange Warsaw Open | type = joint | current = | logo = | logo size = 100px | event name = | city = [[Warsaw]] | country = Poland | founded = | abolished = | location = | venue = [[Warszawianka Courts]] | surface = Clay / Outdoors | website = [http://www.orangewarsawopen.pl www.orangewarsawopen.pl] | notes = | ATP category = [[ATP International Series]]
(2001–2008) | ATP draw = 32S/32Q/16D | ATP prize money = €450,000 | WTA tier = [[WTA Tier IV Events|WTA Tier IV]]
(1998)
[[WTA Tier III Events|WTA Tier III]]
(1999–2004) | WTA draw = 32S/32Q/16D | WTA prize money = }} The '''Orange Warsaw Open''' (former Orange Prokom Open) was an annual men's [[tennis]] [[tournament]] played in [[Poland]] as part of the [[Association of Tennis Professionals|ATP Tour]]. The tournament was played on [[clay court]]s. The men's tournament began in 2001, when the [[San Marino Open]] moved to Sopot. Until 2007, the tournament was held in [[Sopot]], before moving to [[Warsaw]] for 2008. There was also a women's tournament on the same site. It was first organized in 1992 as a lower level competition. In 1998, the tournament became a Tier IV tournament on the [[WTA Tour]]. The next year, it moved up to Tier III. The women's tournament folded in 2004. ==Past finals== ===Men's singles=== {|class="wikitable" |- !Location !style="width:40px"|Year !style="width:200px"|Champions !style="width:200px"|Runners-up !style="width:140px" class="unsortable"|Score |- ! revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/Popajwe|Popajwe]] ([[User talk:Popajwe|talk]]) to last version by Accesscrawl
revision.text:
[[File:Tanumânasî kapalabhati.JPG|thumb|300px|right|{{center|Man practicing Prāṇāyāma}}]] [[File:Lotus Pose .jpg|thumb|300px|right|{{center|Sadhak Anshit practicing Prāṇāyāma}}]] {{Contains Indic text}}
'''Prāṇāyāma''' is a [[Sanskrit]] word alternatively translated as "extension of the ''prāṇa'' (breath or life force)" or "breath control." The word is composed from two Sanskrit words: ''[[prana]]'' meaning life force (noted particularly as the breath), and either ''ayama'' (to restrain or control the prana, implying a set of breathing techniques where the breath is intentionally altered in order to produce specific results) or the negative form ''ayāma'', meaning to extend or draw out (as in extension of the life force). It is a [[Yoga|yogic]] discipline with origins in ancient [[India]].{{fact|date=May 2018}}
==Etymology==
''Prāṇāyāma'' ([[Devanagari]]: {{lang|sa|प्राणायाम}} ''{{IAST|prāṇāyāma}}'') is a Sanskrit compound.
[[Vaman Shivram Apte|V. S. Apte]] provides fourteen different meanings for the word ''prāṇa'' ([[Devanagari]]: {{lang|sa|प्राण}}, ''{{IAST|prāṇa}}'') including these:<ref>Apte, p. 679.</ref>
* Breath, [[Breathing|respiration]] * The breath of life, vital air, principle of life (usually plural in this sense, there being five such vital airs generally assumed, but three, six, seven, nine, and even ten are also spoken of)<ref>For the vital airs as generally assumed to be five, with other numbers given, see: Macdonell, p. 185.</ref> * Energy, vigor * The spirit or soul
Of these meanings, the concept of "vital air" is used by Bhattacharyya to describe the concept as used in Sanskrit texts dealing with prāṇāyāma.<ref>Bhattacharyya, p. 311.</ref> Thomas McEvilley translates ''prāṇa'' as "spirit-energy".<ref>[[Thomas McEvilley|McEvilley, Thomas]]. "The Spinal Serpent", in: Harper and Brown, p. 94.</ref> The [[breath]] is understood to be its most subtle material form, but is also believed to be present in the [[blood]], and most concentrated in men's [[semen]] and women's [[vaginal fluid]].<ref>Richard King, ''Indian philosophy: an introduction to Hindu and Buddhist thought''. Edinburgh University Press, 1999, p. 70.</ref>
Monier-Williams defines the compound ''{{IAST|prāṇāyāma}}'' as "(m., also pl.) N. of the three 'breath-exercises' performed during {{IAST|Saṃdhyā}} (''See'' ''{{IAST|pūrak}}'', ''{{IAST|rechak (English: retch or throw out)}}'', ''{{IAST|kumbhak}}''".<ref>Moner-Williams, p. [http://www.ibiblio.org/sripedia/ebooks/mw/0700/mw__0739.html 706, left column.]</ref> This technical definition refers to a particular system of breath control with three processes as explained by Bhattacharyya: ''{{IAST|pūrak}}'' (to take the breath inside), ''{{IAST|kumbhak}}'' (to retain it), and ''{{IAST|rechak}}'' (to discharge it).<ref name="Bhattacharyya, p. 429">Bhattacharyya, p. 429.</ref> There are also other processes of prāṇāyāma in addition to this three-step model.<ref name="Bhattacharyya, p. 429"/>
Macdonell gives the etymology as ''{{IAST|prāṇa}}'' + ''āyāma'' and defines it as "''m.'' suspension of breath (''sts. pl.'')".<ref>Macdonell, p.185, main entry ''{{IAST|prāṇāghāta}}''</ref>
Apte's definition of ''{{IAST|āyāmaḥ}}'' derives it from ''{{IAST|ā}}'' + ''{{IAST|yām}}'' and provides several variant meanings for it when used in compounds. The first three meanings have to do with "length", "expansion, extension", and "stretching, extending", but in the specific case of use in the compound ''{{IAST|prāṇāyāma}}'' he defines ''{{IAST|āyāmaḥ}}'' as meaning "restrain, control, stopping".<ref>See main article {{lang|sa|आयामः}} ({{IAST|āyāmaḥ}}) in: Apte, p. 224. Passages cited by Apte for this usage are Bhagavatgita 4.29 and Manusmriti 2.83.</ref>
An alternative etymology for the compound is cited by Ramamurti Mishra, who says that:
{{quote|Expansion of individual energy into cosmic energy is called ''{{IAST|prāṇāyāma}}'' (''{{IAST|prāṇa}}'', energy + ''{{IAST|ayām}}'', expansion).<ref>Mishra, p. 216.</ref>}}
==Orthodox Hinduism== ===Bhagavad Gītā=== Prāṇāyāma is mentioned in verse 4.29 of the [[Bhagavad Gita|Bhagavad Gītā]].<ref>Gambhirananda, pp. 217–218.</ref>
According to [[Bhagavad-Gītā As It Is]], ''prāṇāyāma'' is translated to "trance induced by stopping all breathing", also being made from the two separate Sanskrit words, ''prāṇa'' and ''āyām''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iskconpress.com/books/bg/4/29|title=Bhagavad-gītā 4.29 — ISKCON Press}}</ref>
===Yoga Sutras of Patanjali=== {{Yoga Sutras of Patanjali}} Pranayama is the fourth "limb" of the eight limbs of [[Ashtanga vinyasa yoga#Eight Limbs of Ashtanga|Ashtanga Yoga]] mentioned in verse 2.29 in the [[Yoga Sutras of Patanjali]].<ref name="Taimni, p. 205">Taimni, p. 205.</ref><ref>Flood (1996), p. 97.</ref> Patanjali, a Hindu Rishi, discusses his specific approach to pranayama in verses 2.49 through 2.51, and devotes verses 2.52 and 2.53 to explaining the benefits of the practice.<ref>Taimni, pp. 258–268.</ref> Patanjali does not fully elucidate the nature of prana, and the theory and practice of pranayama seem to have undergone significant development after him.<ref name=Pande90_97>G. C. Pande, ''Foundations of Indian Culture: Spiritual Vision and Symbolic Forms in Ancient India''. Second edition published by Motilal Banarsidass Publ., 1990, p. 97.</ref> He presents pranayama as essentially an exercise that is preliminary to concentration, as do the earlier Buddhist texts.<ref name=Pande90_97/>
Many yoga teachers advise that pranayama should be part of an overall practice that includes the other limbs of Patanjali's Raja Yoga teachings, especially [[Yamas|Yama]], [[Niyama]], and [[Asana]].<ref name=Iyengar>{{cite book |title=Light on prāṇāyāma : the yogic art of breathing |year=2011 |publisher=Crossroad |location=New York |author=Bellur Krishnamachar Sundararaja Iyengar |oclc=809217248 }}</ref>
===Hatha yoga=== The Indian tradition of [[Hatha Yoga]] makes use of various pranayama techniques. The 15th century [[Hatha Yoga Pradipika]] is a key text of this tradition and includes various forms of pranayama such as breath retention techniques termed [[Kumbhaka]] and various body locks ([[Bandha (Yoga)|Bandha]]).<ref>James Mallinson (2011). Knut A. Jacobsen; et al., eds. Haṭha Yoga in the Brill Encyclopedia of Hinduism, Vol. 3. Brill Academic. pp. 772-773. {{ISBN|978-90-04-27128-9}}.</ref> Other forms of pranayama breathing include [[Ujjayi breath]] ("Victorious Breath"), [[Bhastrika]] ("bellows breath") and [[Kapalabhati (Hatha Yoga)|Kapalabhati]] ("skull shining breath").<ref>Budilovsky, Joan; Adamson, Eve (2000). The complete idiot's guide to yoga (2 ed.). Penguin. Chapter 7. {{ISBN|978-0-02-863970-3}}.</ref>
Many of these practices have become popular in Western forms of Yoga.
==Buddhism== According to the [[Pali Canon|Pali Buddhist Canon]], the Buddha prior to his enlightenment practiced a meditative technique which involved pressing the palate with the tongue and forcibly attempting to restrain the breath. This is described as both extremely painful and not conducive to enlightenment.<ref>Johannes Bronkhorst, ''The Two Traditions of Mediation in Ancient India.'' Franz Steiner Verlag Weisbaden GmbH, pp. 1–5.</ref> According to the Buddhist scheme, breathing stops with the fourth [[jhana]], though this is a side-effect of the technique and does not come about as the result of purposeful effort.<ref>Johannes Bronkhorst, ''The Two Traditions of Mediation in Ancient India.'' Franz Steiner Verlag Weisbaden GmbH, p. 84.</ref>
The Buddha did incorporate moderate modulation of the length of breath as part of the preliminary tetrad in the [[Anapanasati Sutta]]. Its use there is preparation for concentration. According to commentarial literature, this is appropriate for beginners.<ref>Edward Conze, ''Buddhist Meditation.'' Harper & Row, 1956, p. 66. Regarding the Buddha's incorporation of pranayama see also [[Buddhadasa]], ''Mindfulness with Breathing.'' Revised edition published by Wisdom Publications, 1997, p. 53.</ref>
===Indo-Tibetan tradition=== Later Indo-Tibetan developments in Buddhist pranayama which are similar to Hindu forms can be seen as early as the 11th century, in the Buddhist text titled the ''Amṛtasiddhi'', which teaches three bandhas for [[kumbakha]].<ref>Mallinson, James; 2016. SOAS, University of London. The Amṛtasiddhi: Haṭhayoga's Tantric Buddhist Source Text, pages 1-3 with footnotes</ref>
These developments continued in [[Tibetan Buddhism]] which includes its own forms of pranayama exercises termed [[Lung (Tibetan Buddhism)#Tsa Lung|Tsa-lung]] (Skt: nadi-vayu) usually incorporated into a system of yogic practice such as [[Trul khor]] or into the full [[Tantra|Tantric]] systems of various [[Buddhist Tantras]] such as the [[Six Yogas of Naropa]] of the [[Cakrasamvara]] tradition.<ref>Chogyal Namkhai Norbu, Trans. by Adriano Clemente. Yantra Yoga Snow Lion Publications, page 9</ref> Tibetan Buddhist breathing exercises such as the "nine breathings of purification" or the "Ninefold Expulsion of Stale Vital Energy" (''rlung ro dgu shrugs''), a form of alternate nostril breathing, commonly include visualizations.<ref>Tenzin Wangyal. Awakening the Sacred Body, page 1</ref><ref>{{cite AV media |people=B. Alan Wallace|date= |title=Tsalung Practice-Ninefold Expulsion of Stale Vital Energy |trans-title= |medium=video |language=English |url=http://meridian-trust.org/video/tsalung-practice-ninefold-expulsion-of-stale-vital-energy/ |access-date=2017-08-16 |archive-url= |archive-date= |format= |time= |location=http://meridian-trust.org |publisher=Meridian Trust |id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= |ref= }}</ref>
In the [[Nyingma]] tradition of [[Dzogchen]] these practices are collected in the textual cycle known as "The Oral Transmission of [[Vairotsana]]" (''Vai ro snyan brgyud'').<ref>Chogyal Namkhai Norbu, Trans. by Adriano Clemente. Yantra Yoga Snow Lion Publications, p. 1.</ref>
==Medical== Several researchers have reported that pranayama techniques are beneficial in treating a range of [[stress-related disorders]].<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1002/14651858.CD008250.pub2 | issn = 1469-493X | volume = 10 | pages = CD008250 | last = Holland | first = Anne E. |author2=Hill, Catherine J. |author3=Jones, Alice Y. |author4=McDonald, Christine F. | title = Breathing exercises for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease | journal = The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews | date = 2012 | pmid = 23076942}}</ref> A Cochrane systematic review on the symptomatic relief of asthma by breathing exercises did not find a statistically significant improvement but did find that there was a statistically significant increase in the dose of histamine needed to provoke a 20% reduction in FEV1 (PD20) during pranayama breathing but not with the placebo device.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Freitas DA, Holloway EA, Bruno SS, Chaves GS, Fregonezi GA, Mendonça KP |title=Breathing exercises for adults with asthma |journal=Cochrane Database Syst Rev |volume=10 |issue=CD001277.pub3 |pages= CD001277|date=1 October 2013 |pmid=24085551 |doi=10.1002/14651858.CD001277.pub3 }}</ref>
==Safety== Authoritative texts on Yoga state that, in order to avoid injuries and unwanted side effects, pranayama should only be undertaken when one has a firmly established yoga practice and then only under the guidance of an experienced Guru.<ref name=Iyengar/> Although relatively safe, Hatha Yoga is not risk free. Sensible precautions can usefully be taken such as beginners should avoid advanced moves if they have any physical health related issue. It can get dangerous if someone is trying to pose tough exercise which requires extreme flexibility and good shapes of bones. Hatha Yoga should not be combined with psychoactive drug use, and competitive Hatha Yoga should be avoided. Person should inform the teacher or trainer of their physical limitations and concerns before getting involved themselves for extreme pose positions. Functional limitations should be taken into consideration. Modifications can then be made using props, altering the duration or poses.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Cramer H, Krucoff C, Dobos G |title=Adverse events associated with yoga: a systematic review of published case reports and case series |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=8 |issue=10 |pages=e75515 |year=2013 |pmid=24146758 |pmc=3797727 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0075515 |type=Systematic review }}</ref>
According to at least one study, pranayama was the yoga practice leading to most injuries, with four injuries in a study of 76 practitioners. There have been limited reports of [[adverse effects]] including [[haematoma]] and [[pneumothorax]], though the connections are not always well established.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Cramer H, Krucoff C, Dobos G |title=Adverse events associated with yoga: a systematic review of published case reports and case series |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=8 |issue=10 |pages=e75515 |year=2013 |pmid=24146758 |pmc=3797727 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0075515 |type=Systematic review |quote=The yoga practice that was most often associated with reported adverse events was Pranayama}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

revision.text:
{{infobox hockey team | team = SaPKo | colour = background:#FFFFFF; border-top:#1e264e 5px solid; border-bottom:#ba313b 5px solid; | colour text = black | logo = Savonlinnan Pallokerho logo.svg | logosize = 100px | city = [[Savonlinna]], [[Finland]] | league = [[Mestis]] | conference = | division = | founded = {{Start date|1929}} | operated = | arena = | colours = {{Colorbox|#1e264e}} {{Colorbox|white}} {{Colorbox|#ba313b}} | owner = | GM = [[Vesa Kutvonen]] | coach = [[Pekka Tirkkonen]] | captain = [[Matti Tiihonen]] | affiliates = '''[[KalPa]]''' ([[SM-liiga]]) | parentclub = | farmclub = | website = http://www.sapko.fi/ }}
'''Savonlinnan Pallokerho''' ('''SaPKo''') is an [[ice hockey]] team from [[Savonlinna]], [[Finland]], playing in the [[Mestis]] league. It plays its home matches in [[Winter Salon rink]].
The sports club Savonlinnan Pallokerho was founded in 1929. First it consisted [[association football|football]] and [[bandy]] sections, but since the 1960s ice hockey has been the main sport.
In 1960s SaPKo played four seasons in the highest tier of Finnish ice hockey ''SM-sarja'' but was relegated to Suomi-sarja in 1971. In 1974 the new First Division was formed and SaPKo was one of the teams participating. SaPKo soon established itself as the team of I-divisioona expect few visits to Second Division. In 1968 SaPKo worked its way to the final of Finnish Cup, but lost the final to [[KooVee]] 10-2.
Later bigger success came in the season 1994/1995 when SaPKo had very good regular season with players like [[Canada men's national ice hockey team|Team Canada]] captain [[Brian Tutt]] and was close to promotion to the [[SM-liiga]]. It played tight promotion playoffs against [[Ilves]] but failed to promote. After the success started downtrend which culminated to relegation to ''Suomi-sarja''. At the end of the 2005/2006 season SaPKo finally gained promotion back to the second tier, [[Mestis]].
==Honours==
===Finnish cup=== *{{silver2}} '''[[Finnish Cup (ice hockey)]]''' ''(3)'': 1967, 1968, 2017
===Mestis=== *{{gold1}} '''[[Mestis]]''' ''(1)'': 2017 *{{bronze3}} '''Mestis''' ''(1)'': 2018
==Notable players== * [[Arto Heiskanen]] * [[Jarkko Immonen]] * [[Gennadi Kurdin]] * [[Jukka-Pekka Laamanen]] * [[Ville Leino]] * [[Steve MacDonald (ice hockey)|Steve MacDonald]] * [[Randy Maxwell]] * [[Jarmo Myllys]] * [[Tuukka Rask]] * [[Seppo Repo]] * [[Antti Tirkkonen]] * [[Pekka Tirkkonen]] * [[Paavo Tirkkonen]] * [[Tommi Turunen]] * [[Seppo Aksila]] * [[Brian Tutt]] * [[Viktor Tyumenev]]
==Retired numbers== * '''2''' '''[[Paavo Tirkkonen]]''' * '''3''' '''[[Jyrki Turunen]]''' * '''5''' '''[[Ahti Ruohoaho]]''' * '''10''' '''[[Raimo Turkulainen]]'''
==External links== * [http://www.sapko.fi/ Official homepage]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox cricket tournament | name = Sameer Cup | image = | imagesize = | caption = | administrator = | cricket format = [[One Day International]] | tournament format = [[Round-robin tournament|Round-robin]] and Final | host = {{cr|Kenya}} | champions = {{cr|RSA}} | count = | participants = [[Kenya national cricket team|Kenya]]
[[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistan]]
[[South Africa national cricket team|South Africa]]
[[Sri Lanka national cricket team|Sri Lanka]] | matches = 28 September –
6 October 1996 | attendance = | player of the series = {{flagicon|South Africa}} [[Allan Donald]] | most runs = [[Gary Kirsten]] (227) | most wickets = [[Allan Donald]] (14) }} The '''Kenya Cricket Association Centenary Tournament''' (also known as the '''Sameer Cup''') was a four team [[One Day International|ODI]] cricket tournament held in Kenya during the 1996–97 season. ==Squads== {| border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="text-align:center; font-size:95%; border-collapse:collapse; width:60%;" |- style="background:#C1D8FF;" ! colspan=4|Squads |- style="background:#efefe;" ! style="background:#ccffcc;" scope="row" | {{cr|KEN}}{{citation|url=http://www.cricinfo.com.pk/db/ARCHIVE/1996-97/OD_TOURNEYS/KCA-CT/KCA-CT_SEP-OCT1996_KENYA_SQUAD.html |title=KCA Centenary Tournament – Sep-Oct 1996 – Kenyan Squad |publisher=''[[ESPNcricinfo]]'' |accessdate=12 April 2012}} ! style="background:#ccffcc;" scope="row" | {{cr|PAK}}{{citation|url=http://www.cricinfo.com.pk/db/ARCHIVE/1996-97/OD_TOURNEYS/KCA-CT/KCA-CT_SEP-OCT1996_PAK_SQUAD.html |title=KCA Centenary Tournament – Sep-Oct 1996 – Pakistani Squad |publisher=''[[ESPNcricinfo]]'' |accessdate=12 April 2012}} ! style="background:#ccffcc;" scope="row" | {{cr|RSA}}{{citation|url=http://www.cricinfo.com.pk/db/ARCHIVE/1996-97/OD_TOURNEYS/KCA-CT/KCA-CT_SEP-OCT1996_RSA_SQUAD.html |title=KCA Centenary Tournament – Sep-Oct 1996 – South African Squad |publisher=''[[ESPNcricinfo]]'' |accessdate=12 April 2012}} ! style="background:#ccffcc;" scope="row" | {{cr|SRI}}{{citation|url=http://www.cricinfo.com.pk/db/ARCHIVE/1996-97/OD_TOURNEYS/KCA-CT/KCA-CT_SEP-OCT1996_SL_SQUAD.html |title=KCA Centenary Tournament – Sep-Oct 1996 – Sri Lankan Squad |publisher=''[[ESPNcricinfo]]'' |accessdate=12 April 2012}} |- valign="top" |- | [[Maurice Odumbe]] ([[Captain (cricket)|c]]) | [[Saeed Anwar]] ([[Captain (cricket)|c]]) | [[Hansie Cronje]] ([[Captain (cricket)|c]]) | [[Arjuna Ranatunga]] ([[Captain (cricket)|c]]) |- | [[Rajab Ali]] | [[Azhar Mahmood]] | [[Derek Crookes]] | [[Upul Chandana]] |- | [[Dipak Chudasama]] | [[Ijaz Ahmed (cricketer)|Ijaz Ahmed]] | [[Daryll Cullinan]] | [[Aravinda de Silva]] |- | [[Sandeep Gupta]] | [[Moin Khan]] ([[wicket-keeper|wk]]) | [[Fanie de Villiers]] | [[Sajeewa de Silva]] |- | [[Aasif Karim]] | [[Rameez Raja]] | [[Allan Donald]] | [[Kumar Dharmasena]] |- | [[Hitesh Modi]] | [[Saeed Azad]] | [[Herschelle Gibbs]] | [[Asanka Gurusinha]] |- | [[Thomas Odoyo]] | [[Saleem Elahi]] | [[Andrew Hudson]] | [[Sanath Jayasuriya]] |- | [[Tito Odumbe]] | [[Saleem Malik]] | [[Gary Kirsten]] | [[Romesh Kaluwitharana]] ([[wicket-keeper|wk]]) |- | [[Lameck Onyango]] | [[Saqlain Mushtaq]] | [[Brian McMillan]] | [[Roshan Mahanama]] |- | [[Kennedy Otieno]] ([[wicket-keeper|wk]]) | [[Shahid Afridi]] | [[Craig Matthews]] | [[Muttiah Muralitharan]] |- | [[Tony Suji]] | [[Shahid Nazir]] |[[Jonty Rhodes]] | [[Hashan Tillakaratne]] |- | [[Martin Suji]] | [[Waqar Younis]] | [[David John Richardson|Dave Richardson]] ([[wicket-keeper|wk]]) | [[Chaminda Vaas]] |- | [[Steve Tikolo]] | [[Wasim Akram]] | [[Pat Symcox]] | |- |} ==Schedule== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#efefef" ! colspan="6" | September/October 96 |- ! Date ! Match ! Team 1 ! Team 2 ! Venue ! Result |- || 28 September || [http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/66052.html 1st Match] || {{cr|KEN}} || {{cr|SRI}} || [[Nairobi Gymkhana Club]], [[Nairobi]] || {{cr|SRI}} won by 7 wickets |- || 29 September || [http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/66053.html 2nd Match] || {{cr|PAK}} || {{cr|RSA}} || [[Nairobi Gymkhana Club]], [[Nairobi]] || {{cr|RSA}} won by 62 runs |- || 1 October || [http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/66054.html 3rd Match] || {{cr|RSA}} || {{cr|SRI}} || [[Nairobi Club Ground]], [[Nairobi]] || {{cr|SRI}} won by 2 wickets |- || 2 October || [http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/66055.html 4th Match] || {{cr|KEN}} || {{cr|PAK}} || [[Aga Khan Sports Club Ground]], [[Nairobi]] || {{cr|PAK}} won by 4 wickets |- || 3 October || [http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/66056.html 5th Match] || {{cr|KEN}} || {{cr|RSA}} || [[Nairobi Gymkhana Club]], [[Nairobi]] || {{cr|RSA}} won by 202 runs |- || 4 October || [http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/66057.html 6th Match] || {{cr|PAK}} || {{cr|SRI}} || [[Nairobi Gymkhana Club]], [[Nairobi]] || {{cr|PAK}} won by 82 runs |- || 6 October || [http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/66058.html Final] || {{cr|PAK}} || {{cr|RSA}} || [[Nairobi Gymkhana Club]], [[Nairobi]] || {{cr|RSA}} won by 7 wickets |- valign="top" |} ==Points table== {| class="wikitable" ! Place !! Team !! Played !! Won !! Lost !! Points !! NetRR |- align="center" | 1 || align="left" | {{cr|RSA}} || 3 || 2 || 1 || '''4''' || 1.518 |- align="center" | 2 || align="left" | {{cr|PAK}} || 3 || 2 || 1 || '''4''' || 0.498 |- align="center" | 3 || align="left" | {{cr|SRI}} || 3 || 2 || 1 || '''4''' || 0.496 |- align="center" | 4 || align="left" | {{cr|KEN}} || 3 || 0 || 3 || '''0''' || -2.396 |} ==Final== The final took place between South Africa and Pakistan at the [[Nairobi Gymkhana Club|Gymkhana Club Ground]] in Nairobi. Pakistan had qualified for the final by edging past Sri Lanka on net run rate, largely due to their first innings effort of 9 for 371 when the two teams met. [[Saeed Anwar]] won the toss for Pakistan and elected to bat first. They were all out of 203 in the 46th over with [[Allan Donald|Donald]] and [[Derek Crookes|Crookes]] taking 3 wickets each. Ijaz Ahmed top scored for Pakistan with 47. In reply the South Africans started off well, putting on 77 for the 1st wicket before [[Shahid Afridi]] took a couple of quick wickets. [[Gary Kirsten]] finished unbeaten on 118 off just 127 as his side reached their target in the 39th over. Kirsten was named as the Man of the Match. == References == {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Seasons/KENYA/1996-97_KENYA_Kenya_Cricket_Association_Centenary_Tournament_(Sameer_Cup)_1996-97.html Cricket Archive] {{International cricket tours of Kenya}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sameer Cup 1996-97}} [[Category:International cricket competitions from 1994–95 to 1997]] [[Category:Kenyan cricket seasons to 1999–2000]] [[Category:Sport in Nairobi]] [[Category:1997 in Kenyan cricket]] [[Category:One Day International cricket competitions]] [[Category:International cricket competitions in Kenya]] [[Category:1996 in Kenyan cricket]]
